title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content: NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy stated, "We believe a critical safety issue must be addressed without delay," following the release of urgent safety recommendations regarding helicopter flights near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted the recommendations, noting "And why this information wasn't studied and known before January 29 is an important question." The NTSB is still in "the fact-finding phase" of its investigation, with Homendy explaining, "We still have a lot of work to do in this investigation, so the report contains only the facts that we're able to validate and release at this time," and "The easiest and quickest part of the investigation is determining what happened. The part that takes longer is the how and why." Duffy criticized the current air traffic control system as "antiquated" and pledged to propose a new system, saying "We're at a point where we can do this fast—three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system... It will greatly improve our safety…but it's also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel." Homendy reassured travelers, stating "I just flew with my daughter out of DCA…aviation is incredibly safe," but also noted "However, there are safety issues and areas where we need to improve to make sure that we are at zero."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on aviation safety recommendations, regulatory actions, and accident prevention, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Oxford resident Will Cawley brought concerns about speeding on Tilghman Street to the Commissioners of Oxford, suggesting a speed study from Traffic Concepts Inc. to address the issue. Cawley stated, "Once the speed study is done, then we can reevaluate what the recommendations are and see if we can make some changes to get the speed lowered." Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner noted that pedestrians frequently walk on Tilghman Street, saying "People walk up and down that road, tourists and locals alike," and suggested that sidewalks would be beneficial, but acknowledged that installation wouldn't be simple, saying "Sidewalks would be a great thing to look at. But I also know that putting in sidewalks is not as easy as saying, 'We want a sidewalk.'" Commission President Tom Costigan agreed that a speed study could be considered, saying "It's not an easy process... But it's one we can certainly look into and try." The proposed speed study would provide a report "that details the steps and reasoning used to establish the recommended speed limits." Costigan speculated about the potential outcome, saying "And who knows, they may even like it" after a "period of education."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses traffic safety measures, speed violations, and a town's plan to install stop signs and conduct a speed study, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: September declared National Preparedness Month
content: Geneva Schaffle, division chief of Emergency Management, noted that while Talbot County prepares all year, residents can take steps to be prepared, saying "Our county works really hard with all of our stakeholders to prepare all year long but there are a couple of things people can do to be prepared." Schaffle also advised residents to review their insurance policies, stating "This is also the time to pull out your insurance policies, know what is in your insurance policy and make sure you are prepared for our storm season as we come to a peak here in September." County Manager Clay Stamp emphasized the importance of being informed, saying "An informed community is a strong community," and "The key is to connect with Emergency Services today, on a sunny day, so that when the storm clouds come in, you are connected and get timely information and we can respond to help."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on emergency preparedness, alerts, and disaster response training, which are core public safety issues, though it also mentions a county council proclamation, linking it to local government.

Geneva Schaffle, division chief, Emergency Management

title: Toddlers drown in incident in Greensboro on Sunday
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Two toddlers, a 2-year-old male and a 3-year-old male, drowned in Greensboro on Sunday, according to the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. Deputies responded to the 12000 block of Greensboro Road at approximately 7:30 p.m. on June 29 for a report of a possible drowning. Despite medical treatment from the Caroline County Department of Emergency Services and the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department, both children succumbed to their injuries at Shore Regional Health in Easton. "The Caroline County Sheriff's Office extends its deepest condolences to the family and all those affected by this heartbreaking tragedy," the Sheriff's Office said in a press release. The incident is under investigation by the Caroline County Sheriff's Office Criminal Investigation Division.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a drowning incident involving toddlers and details the response by sheriff's deputies, emergency services, and fire department, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

organizations: Caroline County Department of Emergency Services
Caroline County Department of Social Services

title: Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Dundalk residents viewed the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge with "Shock" and "Shock and dismay," according to Judy Corkhum, who said it "brings back emotions from 9/11. ... You saw that and the first thing you think is, 'Oh my god. The people. The workers.'" Residents, including Corkhum's friend whose son "literally just got over the bridge before it happened," were shaken, with one saying "She said, 'I was having a heart attack this morning thinking he was out on the road last night.'" Anthony Meeks, a Dundalk native, noted, "The Key Bridge is a very iconic piece of Dundalk," and "It's something that everybody who's from Dundalk or this city even has at one point in their life crossed," adding that the collapse "will make me go out of my way to find a different path to get to where I need to go" and "It could make my trips be a lot longer" because "you don't really expect these kinds of tragedies and stuff to happen and occur in your neighborhood." Historical Society Vice President Joe Stadler called the event "unbelievable" and said "It takes a while to fathom it," while noting the bridge's founder, Ben Womer, was "instrumental" in its naming, and describing it as "the backdrop for everything around here." Corkhum lamented, "I'm so used to seeing that pretty view out there every day. It's going to be horrible seeing that (there's) no view anymore."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a sudden bridge collapse, emergency response, and resident safety concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Tramelle Williams was handed two consecutive life sentences without parole for the murders of Taijay Daniels and Lory Fields. Williams' defense had argued for a new trial, claiming evidence related to Daniels' death was "unintentionally admitted and sent back" to the jury in the trial for Fields' death, but the judge denied the motion, stating that the evidence "clearly supported a conviction on all counts," and that the jurors had been instructed to disregard the evidence, and "And they did." Daniels' mother, Barbara Gabbin, described her son as "full of love," saying "Taijay was my world." Fields' daughter Lauren Davis read a letter to her father, stating "I have been so lost without you." The state had argued that the jurors would not have known about Daniels, as "'Taijay Daniels' would be nothing more than a 'John Doe' to the seated jurors."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and court proceedings, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

people: Judge William Jones, Dorchester County Administrative Judge
Amanda Leonard, Dorchester County State's Attorney

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman
author: Natalie Jones
content: Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 41, was arrested and charged with kidnapping, assault, and related charges in connection to Tiyavauna Britt's disappearance. Britt's mother found a note in the car Britt typically drove, which appeared to be "a list of couple goals," with the end of the letter saying "No phones, no kids, just us." Surveillance footage showed a man, identified as Bradley, exiting a vehicle with a woman who appeared to have her hands bound, and audio of the footage revealed "sounds of loud thuds" that "appear to be consistent with forceful strikes." The footage also showed the man "carrying and dragging" what appeared to be a "small statured, light skinned female" with a "limp body." A witness reported hearing a male voice, believed to be Bradley, "started to assault" Britt during a phone call before it suddenly ended, and a "dark object" was seen lying on the ground near the vehicle.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a kidnapping, police investigation, and criminal charges, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content: Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey praised the community's spirit, saying, "I've seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I'm proud to see it all." Debbie Henckel, event organizer, noted the dedication of the officers, stating, "You see a lot of returning officers and you know that's because they care. It's nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids," and "They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community." Henckel also thanked the supporting organizations, saying, "To have their support over the years means more than you know."

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a police‑led community outreach event where officers partner with a local youth club to provide holiday gifts, which directly relates to public safety and community policing activities.

title: Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content:
Here is a summary of the public safety news story in 3-6 sentences:

The Maryland Transportation Authority announced that demolition of the remaining Key Bridge structures will begin around July 7 and take several months to complete. The process will involve heavy machinery to dismantle the bridge, starting with the removal of the bridge deck over the river. "No controlled detonations will occur," the authority said in a release. Nearby communities can expect to see active tug and barge operations, heavy equipment, and trucks, as well as typical large construction project noise from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. Buoys will mark a safety zone around active work areas, and notices will be issued to designate speed restrictions and safety zones. "No significant increase in environmental impacts is expected," the release said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on demolition activities, safety zones, noise and vibration monitoring, and public advisories, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton
author: Contributed
content: Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic for Talbot Emergency Services, said, "We are incredibly proud of this station.It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area," and added that by placing it in a prominent location downtown, "we are hoping that this important resource will be utilized in emergencies by the surrounding community." Michael Smith, head of security at Bluepoint Hospitality, noted that as part of the initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED, and Stop the Bleed, stating, "As part of this initiative, many Bluepoint staffers were certified in CPR, First Aid, AED and Stop the Bleed this year. We hope other downtown businesses join in on the efforts. The more staff that is certified, the better we can serve individuals with life-saving techniques before the professionals arrive." The newly installed AED station is located on Washington Street adjacent to Doc's Downtown Grille.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the installation of a publicly accessible AED and related emergency equipment to improve community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also relates to health.

title: Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
author: Staff Writer
content: A four-seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while landing at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville on April 30, 2025. The plane veered off the runway into a marshy area and came to rest partially in the water. "Although the aircraft sustained significant damage, the sole occupant was not injured," according to Beth Malasky, public information manager for Queen Anne's County. The airport remains closed until an investigation by federal and state aviation authorities is complete, as "there is no damage to the runway," Malasky said. Local fire departments and EMS cleared the scene shortly after noon.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a local aircraft crash and the emergency response, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content: Two people, Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, were arrested for hindering a drug investigation in April. According to the Easton Police Department, Black was stopped on April 4 and a K-9 search discovered "suspected heroin/fentanyl mix," crack cocaine, and ecstasy. During the stop, Black had Wilson call 911 to report a fake shooting at the Easton Walmart. Officers responded but found no evidence of shots fired. Black and Wilson face charges of intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements to police officers, with trials scheduled for November.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police arrests, criminal charges, and a false emergency report, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners
author: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer
content: Sheriff Dan Springer stated that the new Gallatin County Sheriff's Office building is ideally located, noting "Seventy percent of our calls occurring within that radius is pretty significant." The $5.4 million purchase was considered fiscally responsible, as Springer explained, "There wasn't enough money to build a facility... Since we couldn't do that, there wasn't that kind of money available, so we ended up remodeling this to make it more fiscally responsible." The facility features three shooting ranges, with Springer commenting, "We do most of our training here, this is by far the most active bay," and adding that while useful, "You can do movements and cover and all that type of stuff but the only thing I would do differently is try and figure out a way to get a car down here (to train with)." Springer also noted that while shooting practice is a benefit, "We train a lot in shooting, but when you look at the big picture, it's (mostly) traffic stops and domestic responses," and that "(Ranges were) the bonus to the facility. The primary objective when we purchased this was the fact that it's 6.48 acres, in the middle of Four Corners, which is where we're growing and where our primary routes are."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the county sheriff's office, its new building, law‑enforcement operations and public tours, which are core aspects of public safety. It also involves county officials, linking it to local government, but public safety is the primary theme.

title: Automotive Group gives $300,000 to first responder training campus
author: Contributed
content: The Preston Automotive Group donated $300,000 to the Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton. David Wilson Jr., president of Preston Automotive Group, said, "We are grateful to have so many brave men and women putting their lives on the line daily to make sure we are all safe. These men and women are the backbone of our community, the least we could do is contribute to a facility that will help train them and give them the resources they need to be as prepared as possible for situations that come their way while protecting us." Brett Whitehead, co-chairman of the Public Safety Capital Campaign, stated, "The donation from the Preston Automotive Group is an essential first step toward ensuring training available for all emergency services in Talbot County, including our volunteer firefighters, our law enforcement and our emergency services personnel and paramedics. The demand for these services continues to grow on the Mid-Shore and this training campus will help meet this critical need."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a donation to support training for fire, law enforcement, and EMS personnel, which directly relates to public safety services.

title: Dead body found in Walmart parking lot in Denton
author: Konner Metz
content: Denton Police Chief George Bacorn reported that a dead body was found in a vehicle in the Walmart parking lot in Denton on Wednesday afternoon. The police received a call just before 3 p.m. and upon investigation, found the body. Bacorn stated that the investigation is ongoing and noted that there is "no indication of foul play." The cause of death remains undetermined, pending findings from the medical examiner's office, and the person's name has not been released as of Friday.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a dead body found in a public parking lot, which falls under public safety/crime reporting.

title: 2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage
author: Tom McCall
content: A two-structure fire on Stone Boundary Road in Cambridge caused an estimated $850,000 in damage. According to the fire marshal's report, "The fire originated inside the butcher shop shortly after the owner had been doing work inside. Embers from this fire landed on the cedar shingles of the vacant nearby 100+ year old home eventually spreading to the remainder of the house. Both structures are considered a total loss." The fire was controlled after three hours by 75 firefighters, who were assisted by the Tanker Task Force. There were no reported deaths or injuries, but it was noted that there were no smoke alarms present.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a two-structure fire, the emergency response by firefighters, and safety details, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Human trafficking expert hired by For All Seasons
content: Susan Ahlstrom, the new human trafficking navigator for For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center, stated, "I hope to help mitigate the upward trend in Human Trafficking by expanding For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center's outreach; and strengthening the medical, legal, social service, and mental health collaboration that has already been established to support survivors. I believe my counseling and education background, along with strong communication and networking skills will help facilitate the most effective trauma-informed response to serve victims and their families in the Mid-Shore region and beyond." Ahlstrom brings over 25 years of experience working in nonprofit development, community building, education, and youth advocacy to her new role. She was hired as part of the Governor's initiative, the Maryland Regional Navigator Program, to serve human trafficking victims under 24 in the Mid-Shore.

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content: Greensboro Police Chief George Paugh promoted Officer Lenox Trams to lieutenant, saying "Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community," and "You're Mr. Community Policeman." Trams responded, "Well, I'm very humbled," and stated "I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement... It's a great little town" and "I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town." Town manager Tammy Kelledes congratulated Trams, saying "We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job." Paugh, who is leaving to join the Caroline County Sheriff's Office, noted that in seven months, "We made a big impact," listing the department's updates, including a new CAD system, body cameras, and computer systems, all of which were needed "very, very much." Paugh thanked those in attendance, saying "I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's promotion and the police chief's career move, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content: Sgt. Patrick Kepp, a Montgomery County police officer who lost his legs in an attempt to stop a reckless driver, is advocating for new laws to deter negligent driving. "When I was brought into the conversation about new laws being created, right away, I knew it was something I wanted to do," Kepp said. Del. Greg Wims plans to introduce a bill, dubbed "the Sgt. Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving," calling Kepp a "hero," to address "exhibition driving." The bill aims to "give a little more teeth to some of our laws" and stop drivers who have "had a history of speeding and taunting police into chasing him." Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich said the law will "strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer" by stopping behaviors such as "ignoring lights and sirens from law enforcement, breaking the rules of the road … and performing car tricks like drifting, peeling out, and doing donuts in the middle of a road." "All it takes is a moment's loss of control over that vehicle," Elrich warned, "Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident." Kepp and Elrich agree that the current penalties are insufficient, with Elrich noting "It's way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before," and that the new laws will aim to punish repeat offenders without necessarily throwing everyone "in jail, have huge fines, or lose their licenses."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's injury from reckless driving and his push for new traffic safety legislation, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, testified that "when an out-of-hospital cardiac emergency occurs, you have about 600 seconds —10 minutes — to make a difference to save a life before irreversible brain death occurs." After implementing a new CPR training program, Rose reported that "the results have been phenomenal," stating that "we have doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County. They're walking out of a hospital after they've stopped breathing." Prior to the training, 911 operators' experience with CPR training was inconsistent, with Rose saying it "was all over the board," and that "some had it done it yesterday, some had never done it." According to Rose's written testimony, the program improved bystander CPR application from 27% to 43% and increased hospital discharges from five to eleven. Rose noted that "currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program," and that House Bill 1092 "would make it mandatory for 911 centers to provide, not necessarily this particular program, but one similar to it." Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II recalled a cardiac arrest incident during a soccer game, saying "it reminds me of an incident when I used to coach soccer; we had a cardiac arrest incident."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislation and training for 911 operators to provide CPR instructions, focusing on emergency response and public safety infrastructure.

people: Tony Rose, Chief of 911 for Charles County
Ralph E. Patterson II, Commissioner (D), Charles County

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Maryland Sheriffs are calling for Gov. Wes Moore to "immediately demand the resignation" of Vincent Schiraldi, Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, stating that "Since Schiraldi's appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership... have directly made communities less safe in Maryland." Moore's office responded, noting a "concerted effort" to hold youth accountable and rehabilitate offenders "over the past year," with a "26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non-fatal shootings of juveniles." Sheriffs, including Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips, criticized Schiraldi, with Phillips saying, "The law-abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals... They're thugs." Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker also expressed concerns, with Gamble stating there's "no accountability" and Baker saying "juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood." Schiraldi, meanwhile, has indicated he plans to "stay in his job," saying "Gov. Moore has been extremely supportive."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on law‑enforcement officials (sheriffs) demanding the resignation of a state juvenile services secretary due to concerns about juvenile crime and community safety, making public safety the most fitting category.

people: Gov. Wes Moore, Governor of Maryland
Vincent Schiraldi, Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content: Lauren Weber, For All Seasons' vice president of strategy and development, stated that human trafficking persists in Talbot County, saying " … There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries" and " … That persists." Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications, added that "We know that human trafficking knows no boundaries and that it affects people of different backgrounds, races, genders," and that For All Seasons has seen cases from Talbot and neighboring counties, aiming "to be the connector to get those people the help that they need." Weber described the situation as a "double-edged sword," noting a decline in self-referrals but a rapid incline in reports from those who have taken their anti-human trafficking course, saying "But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'" Council Vice President Pete Lesher expressed appreciation for For All Seasons' work, stating "We know that even one victim is too many," and "We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims." A year ago, Weber reported that "a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses human trafficking, a crime and safety concern addressed by a nonprofit and county council, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

title: Suspect still at large following police pursuit
content: Todd Randall Hockensmith, 36, of Felton, remains at large after a pursuit involving Delaware and Maryland police that began on August 25. According to Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker, "The vehicle was reported stolen to the Denton Police Department by Hertrich Chevrolet (in Denton), and we actually located another vehicle on the property that was stolen from them that they didn't even know about." Hockensmith "has three active felony warrants for his arrest for a host of offenses, including theft, burglary and a police pursuit," and is wanted "for the two motor vehicle deaths (of) two brand new cars from Hertrich Chevrolet here in Denton," Baker said.

title: Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Snow has covered Eastern Shore roads since Monday, but counties believe they will be clear by Thursday. Talbot County Public Schools will remain closed on Thursday "due to the continued treacherous road conditions in some parts of the county," according to the district's website. Dorchester County Public Schools will have a virtual day of instruction on Thursday, while Caroline County Public Schools will also be closed. The missed days will not affect the end of the school year, as the districts have inclement weather days built into their calendars. Town officials, such as Rick Van Emburgh and Mark Chandler, report that crews are working to salt and plow roads, and that emergency roads and back roads are being prioritized.

title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content: Leona Demdy, 87, lost many cherished belongings in a fire at her Easton home on Saturday. Demdy said she will miss her photographs the most, stating "I cried, cried, cried," as she watched firefighters extinguish the last embers. She described her extensive photo collection, saying "I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures." Demdy's home of 27 years was one of two houses that caught fire, displacing all residents. The state fire marshal is investigating the cause of the fire.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Star Democrat reported on their top 10 online stories for the week, which included Talbot and Queen Anne's counties being listed as "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the Trump administration, a label that was later disputed by officials. A 12-year-old middle-schooler, Evelyn Klotz, was celebrated for being the youngest to publish a fantasy novel, "Hero of Draconis," and spoke to a sold-out audience at the Flying Cloud Bookstore about her work. Other top stories included a bank robbery, human remains found on a farm, and a serious crash on Route 50. The list was compiled based on page views as of Wednesday evening. The Department of Homeland Security's list that included Talbot and Queen Anne's counties was removed a few days after it was published.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content: Students who completed the Talbot County Sheriff's Office inaugural citizens police academy praised the experience, with Carson Tyree noting, "What stood out is how these guys work. It's not all fun and games," and " … When they go into a situation, there's a lot of thinking behind it because they can't violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can't be a police officer." Fellow student Jules Stepp said, "It was like we were there with them," and expressed surprise at the level of detail involved in policing, stating, "I was surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be," and "And how they have to go through so many processes to get grants, peace orders, protective orders and all that type of stuff." Maj. Steve Elliott thanked the students, calling them a "great group." Lt. J.R Dobson observed, "I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I've seen you all loosen up."

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a citizens police academy run by the Sheriff's Office, focusing on law‑enforcement training and community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Ernest Anthony Vuocolo, 64, received a five-year prison term for stabbing his adult stepson on Thanksgiving Day in 2023. According to court records, Cecil County Sheriff's Office deputies responded to a complaint regarding a "physical domestic involving a knife" and found the victim "bleeding heavily" from his left side. The knife used in the assault was described as being about six inches long with a "thick blade," and was referred to at trial as "field clever." Vuocolo was convicted of second-degree assault, carrying a dangerous weapon with intent to injure, and reckless endangerment, and was sentenced by Judge Cameron A. Brown.

title: Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Zack Cooper, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service Office in Mount Holly, warned that a coastal storm will bring rain and wind to the Eastern Shore late Saturday into Monday, stating "So really starting late in the day Saturday we'll start to see an increase in cloud cover and shower activity, which will ramp up rapidly from there going into Sunday, which is when most of the heavy rainfall will occur, Sunday into Sunday night and going into Monday as well." Cooper advised residents to prepare for the storm, saying "It all starts with just preparation and planning," and recommended staying off roadways in case of minor flooding, noting "A lot of times if there's minor flooding or roadway flooding or things like that the best course of action is to just stay off the roadways."

title: State looks to clear out homeless camp near highway
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: The Maryland State Highway Administration is seeking contractors to clear a homeless camp near Crain Highway and Mattawoman Beantown Road in Charles County, with the contract specifying that the "Contractor shall provide all labor and expertise for surveying, documenting, clean-up, collecting, removal, and disposal services involving homeless encampment abatement actions on MDOT SHA property located in Charles County under an 'as needed' agreement basis." The goal is to restore the site to "a condition without obvious evidence of previous human habitation," according to the contract. Corae Young, chief operating officer of Lifestyles of Maryland, believes that the current encampment may be a relocation of a previous camp in the area, stating "I believe what occurred is people moved close by." The State Highway Administration works with local agencies to assist those residing on state rights-of-way, with Daniel Allman saying "SHA works in partnership with local agencies... to assist those residing on state rights-of-way. Connecting them with agencies that can provide relocation assistance, housing or other support services has proven to be a successful approach." Despite the contract being put out to bid, Allman noted that "At this time, there is no work scheduled for this location."

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content: Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy, began the ceremony by saying, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes. It is our duty to never forget them, for they have paved the path forward with their lives. The path leading us here tonight was born from tragedy. Incredible losses. Unbearable pain for our families, friends, and the community. These honored in front of you served our community with pride, dignity, and honor. Knowing their lives could, at any moment be taken, so that we may live. So that we may continue on the path they have now paved." Sue Nickerson, mother of fallen officer Michael Nickerson, explained the significance of the event, stating "The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne's County deputy) were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne's County," and added "It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters and our EMTs have done. It is very much appreciated." The names of the fallen heroes were read, including "Buck" Clough and "Dougie" Thomas. Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson spoke about stoicism, saying "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us. We don't have any control over that. But what we do have control over is how we respond to it, how we react, how we pick up the pieces and go on. Stoicism also places an emphasis on appreciating the unity and precious gift of life." A radio transmission echoed "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland. May their dedication and sacrifice never be forgotten and may they rest in eternal peace." Rev. Karen Handy closed with a prayer, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others. Lord, mend those hearts that are broken in the loss of these loved ones. Lord, we pray that this memorial tonight has brought a bit of peace. Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons. We thank you and pray for those that they have left behind."

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a memorial ceremony honoring fallen police, fire, and EMS personnel, which is directly related to public safety and first‑responder activities.

title: Cambridge man gets 25 years after taking plea deal in murder trial
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Daeveon Johnson, 19, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for the 2021 fatal shooting of Ja'Len Woolford. According to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard, "The Court heard heartfelt victim impact statements from three members of the victim's family, each expressing their choice to forgive Mr. Johnson, and each requesting the Court consider a lesser period of active incarceration for Mr. Johnson given his cooperation and remorse." The State had recommended a sentence of life imprisonment, suspending all but 40 years of active incarceration. Johnson entered an Alford plea and will be eligible for parole after serving 50% of his sentence.

title: Crane accident at power substation leaves much of Caroline County without power Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: A crane accident at a Delmarva Power substation in Denton left over 1,100 Caroline County residents without power on Thursday. According to Delmarva Power, "Due to the extent of the repairs, we were able to restore 850 customers in just over two hours, with the remaining 300 customers restored two hours later, just before 1 p.m." Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding said, "Delmarva Power's intergovernmental affairs liaison reached out to me," and kept him updated on the progress. The power outage caused disruptions in schools, with Breeding noting "I know it. It caused some havoc in a few of our schools, Breeding said." Caroline County and the town of Denton offered warming shelters, but none were utilized. Delmarva Power restored power to the area around 1 p.m., with Choptank Electric confirming all their customers had power restored by 1:45 p.m.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman
author: Maggie Trovato
content: A Cambridge man, Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, has been charged with murder, kidnapping, and other crimes in connection with the disappearance and murder of 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt. According to the Maryland State Police, Bradley was indicted on these charges on March 29 and is being held without bail. Britt's body has not been found, and her vehicle was discovered unoccupied in the Dollar Tree parking lot in Easton with her belongings, including her phone and wallet, inside. Britt's mother had reported being unable to contact her daughter and feared for her safety due to a history of domestic violence with Bradley, her ex-boyfriend. The investigation is ongoing, and police are asking anyone with knowledge of Britt's whereabouts to contact Sergeant Scott Sears at 443-783-7230.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation, charges, and police actions related to kidnapping and murder, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Mid-Shore preps for National Night Out Aug. 5
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: St. Michaels Police Department Chief Jeffery Oswald invites members of the community to National Night Out on August 5, stating that attendees can "enjoy a hamburger with the fire department, see new law-enforcement equipment, and reconnect with old friends. All of our local partners will be in attendance as we recognize those in the community who have donated their time and care towards a safer St. Michaels." The event is part of a national community building campaign that promotes police-community partnerships and neighborhood camaraderie. Multiple Mid-Shore municipalities, including Easton, Caroline County, and Dorchester County, will also be celebrating National Night Out. National Night Out aims to enhance the relationship between neighbors and law enforcement, bringing back a sense of community.

title: Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler reported that a small electrical fire broke out in a special education room at Queen Anne's County High School on September 9, causing the school to be closed for a day. The preliminary cause of the fire was deemed accidental, resulting from "an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector," according to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal. Queen Anne's County Public Schools (QACPS) expressed gratitude to first responders and staff, stating on Facebook: "We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately." The fire was brought under control in about 30 minutes, with estimated damages of $30,000. Normal operations resumed on September 11.

title: Cambridge theater has another incident of smoke in theater
content: Fire crews responded to the Cambridge Premier Cinema on August 9 for a report of smoke, the second incident in two weeks. The August 9 and July 29 incidents were determined to be a malfunction in an air handler on the roof of the theater. "Fire crews respond to a call for smoke in a movie theater on July 29 in Cambridge," according to a photo caption. Multiple fire companies and emergency personnel responded to each incident.

title: Federalsburg police chief resigns; sheriff's office takes over leadership
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Federalsburg Mayor Kim Abner announced that Police Chief Joseph Gasser resigned effective June 25, stating "The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25." The Caroline County Sheriff's Office will take over leadership of the department temporarily. Sheriff Donald Baker said, "I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day-to-day operations and management oversight of the department," and "I agree to do that on an interim basis for 30 to 60 days until the mayor and council decide what they are going to do moving forward and what that looks like for the Federalsburg Police Department." Baker noted that all options are being considered, saying "I believe that everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley's, directly with the sheriff's office of the county," and "Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left." A public forum to discuss the department's future is scheduled for July 21.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the resignation of a town police chief and the sheriff's office assuming interim leadership, which directly pertains to public safety matters.

title: Fire causes $1 million in damage to pizzeria
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: A fire at Mario's Pizza near Elkton, Maryland, caused an estimated $1 million in damage, forcing the business to close indefinitely. The blaze was discovered at 9:57 p.m. on Tuesday by a neighboring employee, who called 911. Approximately 75 firefighters battled the blaze for about 20 minutes before bringing it under control. According to a Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal spokesperson, the fire caused "$600,000 in structural damage to the pizzeria part of the building, ... and it destroyed approximately $400,000 in property inside the shop." The spokesperson, who identified Mario Testa as the owner, reported that no one was injured.

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief

content: Greensboro's new Police Chief Lenox Trams said, "We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves," as he outlined his plans to fill out the department with three more officers. Trams' former colleague, Sgt. Al Orrison, praised him, saying "When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it's hard to have compassion all the time," but added, "But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he's just an incredible human being." Orrison also shared a personal anecdote, stating Trams "took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man." EPD Sgt. David Trevino also praised Trams, saying "The town of Greensboro is very fortunate."

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content:
Here is the summary:

The legalization of recreational cannabis in Maryland has forced local law enforcement agencies to rebuild their K-9 units, as dogs trained to detect marijuana are no longer effective in court. According to Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, "I really didn't want to go down the road because I didn't want to be challenged in the courtroom." Easton Police Department's Lt. Tim Larrimore notes that "This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that's out," and now they need dogs that can detect other substances, stating "It's the dog that gets you there." Sergeant Scott Lockerman of the Maryland Police K9 Foundation says "Most of the agencies were able to replenish the dogs," while Dorchester County Sheriff James Phillips remarks that "We saw it coming, It was on the horizon," and finds the community's generosity in donating dogs "mind-boggling." Phillips adds that having K-9s "completes the police agency" and pays off "10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people," with Sgt. Steve Twilley noting that K-9s help build trust with kids, saying "Next thing you know, that kid's come to you for help instead of lashing out or doing something at school." Pfc. Mark Schinault describes K-9 Knox as driven, stating "That means the world to her, so she's very driven to work." Larrimore notes that the cost of caring for retired K-9s "hasn't hit us yet," as "These dogs are just retired last year. They're young, they're healthy." Phillips and others agree that K-9 units are essential, with Phillips stating "I think an agency that's trying to do today's police work and doesn't have the K-9 ability out there, I don't think they're a full police agency," and "I think it completes the police agency by having the K-9s."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police K‑9 units, their operational challenges, funding, and community impact, which are core aspects of public safety rather than broader government or economic topics.

title: Easton man charged with eight counts of child porn possession
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Travis Schwaninger, 42, of Easton, Maryland, was arrested on June 11 and charged with eight counts of possession of child pornography. The Talbot County Sheriff's Office led the investigation, which was initiated after the Easton Police Department received tips about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children in April. title: Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Council Member Brandy James stated, "We felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public." The Federalsburg Town Council is creating a Memorandum of Understanding with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to establish policing duties, replacing the town's police department. The proposed agreement assigns four officers to the town for a one-year contract, with a cost of $863,000, saving the town $280,000 compared to the current $1.146 million annual cost. The town plans to hold regular check-ins with the public as part of the agreement.

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content: Maryland Governor Wes Moore stated, "In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk," and added, "These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community." Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld said, "The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads," and "The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders." Various local leaders expressed gratitude for the grants, including Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio-Lopez, who said, "As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment and support of our county and state partners so that we can deliver safety for our residents, businesses and visitors," and "While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve." Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski stated, "Investing in our roadways not only improves vital infrastructure, but prioritizes the safety and wellbeing of our residents and communities," and "We are grateful to our federal and state partners for their help with the critical planning projects supported with this grant - and for helping to ensure Baltimore County's roads are safe for years to come." Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran said, "This federal grant will help our local, state and federal partners combine knowledge and resources to create a comprehensive highway safety plan that will improve safety for our citizens and everyone traveling though Queen Anne's county." Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout expressed, "We're grateful for the funding. It's the kind of thing small communities need."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on MDOT grants aimed at reducing traffic fatalities and improving road safety (Vision Zero), which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also involves local government entities receiving the funds.

title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Mark William Thompkins, 25, of Preston pleaded guilty to attempted second-degree murder on November 1, 2023, in connection with a February 2022 stabbing. According to Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin, Thompkins stabbed a 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road in Preston, then held a knife to his own throat. Thompkins was detained after a 15-minute standoff, during which he punctured his own neck with a knife, and was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center. The state's attorney will recommend a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years suspended, followed by five years of supervised probation. Sentencing is set for February 1, 2024, as stated by the court, with State sentencing guidelines recommending five to 10 years, according to Jesse Hicks, Thompkins' attorney.

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: A Chestertown pediatrician, Julio Ramirez, has surrendered his license to practice in Maryland amid allegations of abuse. Four former employees of Ramirez "all testified to a pervasive environment of sexually abusive, unethical, and inappropriate behavior," according to an investigation report. The Maryland State Board of Physicians ordered a summary suspension of Ramirez's license, concluding "the public health, safety or welfare imperatively required emergency action in this case." Ramirez's practice had aimed "to better serve the Queen Anne's and neighboring communities." Attorneys for a woman suing Ramirez stated, "As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us." Upon closing his practice, Ramirez announced, "It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently. Due to unforeseen circumstances, and after careful deliberation, I have decided to retire and close my practice... I would like to thank you for your time and the trust you have given me during our many years of operation in Chestertown. Taking care of your family was an honor and a privilege for me and my staff."

title: Cambridge man charged with armed carjacking, robbery
content: A Cambridge man, Kevin McClain, 53, was arrested on October 27 on 36 charges, including armed carjacking and robbery, stemming from an October 3 incident. According to police, the charges relate to an armed robbery on Caribbean Avenue, where a victim was knocked to the ground and robbed at gunpoint by a 17-year-old boy, who then fled with McClain in the victim's vehicle. Police identified McClain as the "friend" of the victim who accompanied the teen during the getaway. McClain was transported to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond after his initial court appearance.

title: A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, executive director of Talbot Humane, and Karen Culotta, director of the Caroline County Humane Society, reported a significant increase in dog and cat intake at their shelters. Crankshaw-Quimby stated, "This is a trend we are seeing across the country," and added, "I am the president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland, the state association of shelters and animal control agencies, and we are seeing crisis level intake in our larger municipalities." Culotta speculated that the influx may be economically driven, saying, "For some people, with the cost of vet care going up, with the cost of everything going up, or, since the pandemic, sometimes (people) can't afford to feed their animals or can't afford to get vaccinations, which is required of every cat and dog in the state of Maryland," and noted, "It's very challenging for everybody here." Crankshaw-Quimby emphasized the importance of programs like foster, spay/neuter, and intervention, stating, "We work very hard to keep animals out of the shelter with our robust assortment of programs; however... one large animal control seizure or a wave of animal surrenders could put us over the top," and "This is why the foster, spay/neuter and intervention programs are so very important." Culotta described the rise in intake as "odd."

title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Organizations on the Shore hosted a count of people experiencing homelessness, revealing a growing population and a shortage of resources. Ashley Kessinger, continuum care manager at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, described the crisis, saying, "Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough." Yvette Robinson, grant manager at Neighborhood Service Center, noted, "The numbers are growing, the resources are not," and added, "We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources." Kessinger emphasized that homelessness can affect anyone, stating, "People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way," and "There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home."

title: Motorcyclist killed in U.S. 50 Sunday morning crash
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: A motorcyclist, identified as Cody Morris, was killed in a U.S. Route 50 crash early Sunday morning. According to an official with the Maryland State Police Centreville barracks, Morris' 2005 Yamaha FZR600 motorcycle went off the roadway and struck the center guardrail at approximately 12:35 a.m. Morris was thrown into the roadway, where he was struck by two vehicles traveling westbound. Morris was pronounced dead at the scene by responding emergency medical services. The incident is currently under investigation.

title: Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school
author: Konner Metz
content: Local police and emergency medical professionals participated in active shooter drills at The Country School in Easton on Thursday. According to the National Center for Education Statistics, active shooter situations in schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2022. Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill, demonstrating the importance of first responders from different counties working together under stress. As Cpl. Tull showed, "officers and EMTs didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way," highlighting the value of the training.

author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Lance Cephas stated that "25 kids should not take this whole city down" and emphasized the need to educate children caught in wrongdoing, saying "Because if you send them back home to that same environment, ain't nothing going to happen" and "A lot of police officers, they'll pick them up, they'll let them go, and soon as they're around the corner, they've done something else to somebody else. So you've got to get them and educate them." He urged the council to work together, saying they shouldn't be "at each other's throats" and "controlled by 25 kids," and instead "We've all got to come together." Sputty Cephas noted that Commissioner Atkiss said "$100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent," a sentiment he understood from his banking experience, and suggested finding middle ground on curfew fines. Theresa Stafford identified poverty as a "lead driver" for issues in Cambridge, advocating for better-paying jobs and education to combat crime, saying "Bringing in industries or businesses that will pay good wages, and of course, supporting getting kids educated because that's the other key driver that keeps driving up the crime."

title: Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says

content: Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd stated that crime in Cambridge is "trending down," attributing the decrease to officers being "out doing what we're asking of them to do as an administration" with "patrol with a purpose, be in our high-crime areas." Todd said, "But we're making progress," despite acknowledging that there's still work to be done, particularly with juvenile reform, as Cambridge is "stagnant" in this area. Todd emphasized the need to "put more emphasis on figuring out why these kids are out committing these crimes and getting in touch with families by working through social services and Juvenile Services." title: Bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities
author: SOfIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service
content: Del. Kym Taylor, a Democrat representing Prince George's County, stated that "There are no visible signs nor immediate indicators to help first responders understand potential reactions" when interacting with individuals with invisible disabilities. Prince George's County Sheriff John Carr supports the proposed bill, saying that increased resources to aid people with invisible disabilities during encounters with law enforcement are a "must." Carr added, "From a law enforcement perspective, we want you to know that we are here to serve you and we want this bill to pass," and that easing citizens' concerns during traffic stops "helps us interact and keep our community safe." The bill, known as Eric's ID Law, would allow individuals to request a notation on their driver's license or state ID card indicating their unseen disability and mandate training for law enforcement, similar to existing initiatives like the MVA "blue card" and the Ethan Saylor Alliance, which aims to "provide increased training for law enforcement and other public service entities."

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
author: Konner Metz
content: Easton's new fire chief, J.R. Dobson, is planning to focus on equipment and recruitment after being elected to the department's top role in December. Dobson, who grew up around the firehouse and recalls the "everybody knew everybody" aspect, said "There's a lot of tradition here," and noted that the department is a business where "we're all here for free, none of us get paid." title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content: House Speaker Adrienne Jones stated that "Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps" in the current youth justice system. Senate President Bill Ferguson emphasized the need for "accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system," and said "We must ensure that all parts are working to their highest potential." title: Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot and Queen Anne's counties disputed being labeled "sanctuary jurisdictions" by the Trump administration, with Queen Anne's County stating the designation was "wholly inaccurate" and saying "Queen Anne's County has never adopted or endorsed sanctuary policies, nor have we enacted any ordinances or resolutions that would shield individuals in violation of federal immigration law," and "We have, and will continue to, follow all applicable federal laws and have not taken any deliberate actions to obstruct their enforcement," while "welcoming further information and guidance from the federal government so we can address any pertinent issues." 
DHS Secretary Kristi Noem said the department is "exposing these sanctuary politicians who harbor criminal illegal aliens and defy federal law," and that "These sanctuary city politicians are endangering Americans and our law enforcement in order to protect violent criminal illegal aliens." 
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble expressed concern over a potential loss of a federal grant, saying "We hope that we can reapply and renew that grant," after being put on the list, which was a "total shock" to him, adding "They haven't asked us to do anything," and "We haven't said no to anything." 
Queen Anne's County Sheriff Gary Hofmann said "This is continued misinformation that's been perpetuated now," and "I've heard this for a couple years, so it's of no surprise," stating his office "hasn't changed on how we deal with criminals," with a "zero tolerance" approach. 
The Department of Homeland Security listed jurisdictions based on "compliance with federal law enforcement, information restrictions, and legal protections for illegal aliens," and federal agencies are directed to identify federal grants and contracts for potential "suspension or termination, as appropriate."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on immigration enforcement, sanctuary designations, and potential impacts on law‑enforcement grants, which are core public safety issues, while also involving county officials, making Public Safety the strongest match.

title: Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: Sarah Johnson, Warning Coordinator Meteorologist for the National Weather Service, encouraged attendees at a Kent County Public Library workshop to become informed weather spotters, stating "That's why we need you all." Johnson emphasized that people tend to be more alert during a "tornado warning" than a "severe thunderstorm warning," but stressed "That's a mistake to think one's worse than the other." She highlighted that 75% of fatalities in the US are due to water, saying "When we look at the fatalities, 75% in the United States are due to water in some way; 50% of those are due to storm surge; 25% freshwater heavy rain flooding. Keep that in mind. Don't think, 'Oh, it's just a tropical storm.' No, you still need to pay attention and see what the hazards are." As the movie "Twisters" is released, Johnson hopes to educate citizens rather than encourage storm chasing.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a workshop that trains volunteers to report severe weather, emphasizing preparedness and life‑saving actions, which aligns most closely with public safety rather than purely educational or governmental topics.

people: Sarah Johnson, Warning Coordinator Meteorologist, National Weather Service

title: Youth not facing consequences for breaking laws
author: Thomas R. Hurley; Fraternal Order Of Police
content: Thomas R. Hurley, president of the Fraternal Order of Police, Cambridge-Dorchester Lodge No. 27, stated that due to new laws in Maryland, "not be charged with any crime is under 10 years old." He expressed concern that this law, along with others, is causing an increase in juvenile crime and will lead to more serious problems as these children grow up without consequences for their actions. Hurley noted that the police are now limited in their ability to address these issues, and are instead having to refer juveniles to social services for counseling. The Fraternal Order of Police is calling on citizens to contact their lawmakers and express their opposition to these new laws.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses recent changes to juvenile criminal law and their impact on policing and community safety, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Cambridge police ready for National Night Out
author: Lily Tierney
content: Cambridge Police Sgt. Antione Patton stated that "Most of the time, the only time the community and the children get opportunities to engage with law enforcement is at a call, and normally that is when people are at their worst," as he prepared for the department's National Night Out event. Patton explained that the event aims to provide a positive interaction between the community and law enforcement, saying "And we want people that are having a good time, to actually have time to talk to police officers about other things than problems and issues." The event will feature activities such as pumpkin decorating and a pie-eating contest at Great Marsh Park on October 7.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police department organizing a community event (National Night Out) to foster positive interaction between law enforcement and residents, which directly relates to public safety initiatives.

title: Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: A $235,000 settlement has been reached between the family of Anton Black, who died in police custody in 2018, and the state medical examiner. The settlement "makes necessary changes to the Maryland Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's process for autopsies conducted on people killed in law enforcement custody and requires notification to families about the results and their rights to challenge the results." Richard Potter, founder of the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black, called the settlement an "excellent first step" and said, "I hope that with this settlement agencies will begin to recognize their own wrongdoings... What is needed is a sense of shared ownership that can only come through trust and mutual accountability, with police confronting their own biases about mental illness, committing to de-escalation, and truly serving a diverse community." Sonia Kumar, a senior staff attorney with the ACLU of Maryland, described the settlement as "hardfought" and said, "We can't prevent such deaths if we aren't honest about what caused them, and this settlement is a crucial step towards that goal in future cases... We hope this settlement will make a real, positive impact, but it is truly just the beginning of the reckoning needed to address decades of misrepresentations so we can bring justice to families still waiting for the government to tell the truth." The reforms also aim to instill "independence from improper law enforcement influence."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police restraint death, settlement, and reforms to police and medical examiner practices, which are core issues of public safety. Race & Diversity is also relevant due to the focus on a Black victim and systemic bias, while Local Government is involved through the Board of Public Works approval.

title: Caroline County leaning towards not going forward with Regional Detention Center
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Caroline County Commissioners President Travis Breeding expressed concerns about a regional detention center agreement, stating "Unfortunately, because of their schedule and their pay scale, I don't think Caroline County is going to save any money by entering into the agreement," and "If we're not going to save any money, why relinquish the autonomy that we have right now to operate as our own facility and better suit the needs of the Caroline County as opposed to a three-county organization." "I just don't see the the upside at this point," he said. The potential detention center would be located at the former Eastern Pre-Release Unit site. Breeding said, "We appreciate the the time and and the effort that Kent, Queen Anne's and our staff have put into researching this, we did our due diligence, and we just don't feel that it's going to be advantageous for us to enter into the three-county agreement," Breeding said, adding the county spent a lot of time studying the proposal. According to the draft agreement, "The Board shall appoint a Warden to operate the Facility with the consent of the County Commissioners of Queen Anne's County." The draft agreement also stated that "The Warden's contract shall not be terminated without the Board's consent".

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on county officials debating participation in a regional detention center, a facility directly related to public safety and corrections, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Talbot County Public Schools' director of communications, Debbie Gardner, stated that the safety of students and staff is always the top priority. "The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools," Gardner said. She added, "Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature." The incident involved three students and resulted in one being transported to the hospital for non-life-threatening injuries.

title: UPDATE: Bay Bridge reopened to most traffic, wind restrictions in place
author: Staff Writer
content: The Chesapeake Bay Bridge was closed to all traffic due to gusts exceeding 55 miles per hour, but has since reopened to most traffic in both directions. "Motorists should expect significant delays," according to the report. Wind restrictions are in place for vehicles vulnerable to high winds, including house trailers and empty box trailers. Severe weather was expected to remain in the area until Wednesday evening.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a temporary bridge closure and traffic restrictions due to hazardous wind conditions, which is primarily a public safety issue concerning transportation safety.

title: Old mill to be demolished
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: Council President Ashley Kaiser stated that the town's new ordinance is "a step in the right direction and puts us in line with a lot of towns around us." The Centreville Town Council has announced plans to demolish the old mill building at 2647 Centreville Road, deeming it a dangerous structure that poses a risk to public safety. The property owner has 10 days to demolish the building, or the town will do so. In related news, Council Member Jim Beauchamp, who has served on and off the council for 10 years, is up for re-election but plans to withdraw if both other candidates move forward, saying "It's been a good 10 years."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the demolition of a dangerous building and the council's actions to mitigate a public safety risk, making Public Safety the strongest match, with Local Government as a close secondary topic.

title: Federalsburg apartment fire displaces 14
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A July 5 fire at the Federalsburg Manor Apartments displaced 14 people. The fire broke out shortly after 7 p.m. and took 30 firefighters about 30 minutes to control, resulting in an estimated $400,000 in damages. According to the fire marshal's report, the fire was discovered in the bedroom of an apartment by the occupant, who attempted to extinguish the blaze with a bucket of water but was unsuccessful, before calling 911. No injuries were reported, and the American Red Cross is assisting those displaced.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a residential fire, emergency response, displacement of residents, and involvement of the fire marshal and Red Cross, which are core aspects of public safety.

title: After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm
author: Natalie Jones
content: Local school districts canceled after-school activities on Tuesday due to a powerful storm system, with possible delays or closures on Wednesday. Dorchester County Public Schools will operate on a two-hour delay schedule Wednesday, while Queen Anne's County Public Schools will have a 90-minute delayed opening. "The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties," said Mike Lee, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Philadelphia/Mount Holly office. A coastal flood warning and flood watch are in effect for several counties, with widespread roadway flooding and potentially significant flooding expected. Gov. Wes Moore enacted a State of Preparedness declaration on Tuesday morning.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on storm‑related hazards, flood warnings, and emergency directives, emphasizing safety measures and public alerts, which aligns best with Public Safety.
