title: Cambridge man arrested on 30 charges following vehicle pursuit
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Keizye Daijuon Collins, 27, of Cambridge, was arrested on 30 charges after a vehicle pursuit on July 1. According to the Cambridge Police Department, Collins fled a traffic stop "at a high rate of speed" and "swerved" at a police patrol vehicle, causing the officer to "had to make evasive maneuvers to avoid being struck." Collins struck a house on Charles Street and Skinners Court before fleeing on foot. He was later identified as the driver and arrested on July 8 on an arrest warrant. Collins was turned over to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police pursuit, arrest, and criminal charges, which falls squarely under public safety matters rather than other categories.

title: Fire Marshal investigates abandoned mobile home fire
author: Maggie Trovato
content: The Office of the State Fire Marshal has determined that the preliminary cause of a fire in an abandoned mobile home on Kibler Road in Greensboro was incendiary. The fire was discovered by a passerby on Tuesday and resulted in an estimated loss of $1,000. The mobile home had been vacant for over 15 years and the fire did not cause any injuries or deaths. It took 12 firefighters 30 minutes to control the one-alarm fire, with the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company as the primary responding department. The exact origin of the fire remains unclear.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire investigation by the State Fire Marshal, focusing on fire cause and response, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress
author: Connie Connolly
content: The Caroline County Police Accountability Board Chairman John Bartlett stated that the Sheriff's Office had over 26,000 calls for service in 2023, generating only six complaints, saying "I think that speaks volumes with law enforcement here in Caroline County." The Board's role "is to receive police complaints, recommend policy changes and identify any trends," according to Administrator Kimberly Raeder, while the Administrative Charging Committee "look over and review completed complaint investigations and recommend discipline" to "decide what kind of discipline would be necessary based on the complaint." Bartlett highlighted one "very important" point, and the Board identified a trend of officers not activating body cameras, stating "A common identified trend, however, has been the lack of activation of body cameras when officers interact with the public." The Board recommends changing the law to only mandate complaints of "matters of public concern," such as "police misconduct, such as abuse of power, false arrest, police brutality, or criminal activity" and handling "Rude and discourteous" behavior at the department level, and also suggests "changing ACC training from all in-person training to online meeting based or pre-recorded online training."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the Caroline County Police Accountability Board, complaints against law enforcement, and oversight policies, which are primarily matters of public safety, though they also involve local government structures.

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Executive Director Robin Davenport said, "The people who bring our mission to life are our CASA volunteers." Davenport emphasized the importance of the volunteers, stating, "And that is really important to us, but certainly to the future of the kids who we're working with." Volunteer Larry Neviaser noted that CASA volunteers "don't represent anybody else except the child," and felt supported by the organization's staff, saying "They recognize the value of the volunteers, and (that) it really makes the organization." Author and speaker Frank Kros inspired the volunteers, saying "It's incredible what we can do when someone genuinely believes in us and provides us the support that we need."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on CASA volunteers who advocate for children at risk and under court protection, which relates to child safety and protection services, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Meet the bikers who try – and fail – each year to erode Maryland’s helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content: Bob Spanburgh, Maryland ABATE's board chairman, said, "But we keep introducing it. We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we're nuts, probably." The bill, named after Gary "Pappy" Boward, aims to make helmets optional for riders over 21 with a safety course. Sen. Mike McKay stated, "I firmly believe that we as government do better when we educate people, [rather] than legislating something," and "There are people that would like to have the choice [to not wear a helmet.] And I tend to believe that we should give people the choice but 100% support educating them about it." Spanburgh became an activist after joining ABATE, recalling, "At the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me [was,] 'You got to register to vote. It's very important in this organization,'" and "That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time." Del. Jay Jacobs described ABATE members as "diehards for what they believe in," saying "Thank God they do. They don't let go of this stuff. It's a tough fight over here to get that kind of legislation passed." Sen. Jill Carter noted, "I don't agree with them that they shouldn't wear a helmet, but I do agree about the civil liberty issue," and "They are adamant as dedicated motorcyclists that this is not something they want mandated to them." Gene Ransom, CEO of MedChi, argued, "A lot of people might say, 'Well, it's my free will to do whatever I want to do, no matter how stupid it is,'" and "The problem is, when it comes to healthcare … your decision then ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money." Ken Eaton, Maryland ABATE's executive director, said, "If I don't do it, who else is going to do it?" The bill is scheduled for a hearing before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legislative effort to change Maryland's mandatory helmet law, a matter directly tied to traffic safety and public health outcomes, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County officials broke ground on a new EMS station in Cordova to reduce ambulance wait times. Brian LeCates, director of the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, said, "We always try to make sure that we are to our calls within eight minutes, at least 95% of the time," and noted that the area was previously underserved, stating "And this is an area that was underserved by that." Council President Chuck Callahan said the $2.1 million project comes at an important time as renovations progress at the nearby elementary school. 
Council members fully funded the project, which will be the county's sixth paramedic station. It will include space for a 24/7 paramedic and EMT unit.
Callahan thanked the Gannon family for their land, saying "Callahan said. Jimmy Eason, president of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association, said the station is welcomed "with open arms."  Eason said. LeCates also acknowledged Sylvia Gannon, a former County Council member and founding member of the Talbot Paramedic Foundation, for her loyalty to Talbot County's EMS efforts.

title: Be responsible on the water
author: Staff Writer
content:
Here is a summary of the story in 3-6 sentences:

The National Safe Boating Council is promoting safe boating practices during National Safe Boating Week (May 17-23). CAPT. BRETT M. SAUSE, a USCG master licensed captain, notes several tips for safe boating, including wearing a U.S. Coast Guard-approved life jacket and knowing state boating laws. "Accidents on the water can happen much too fast to reach and put on a stowed life jacket," the campaign warns. Other tips include taking a boating safety course, filing a float plan, and being aware of carbon monoxide poisoning from gasoline-powered engines. Boaters are also advised not to drink while boating, as "alcohol was listed as a leading factor in boating-related deaths" where the primary cause was known.

title: Telling the truth matters
author: Staff Writer
content: The Dorchester County Republican Central Committee recently claimed that protesters were being brought to the area on buses, but this is not accurate, according to Sydney Bradner-Jacobs. "While some protesters come from other counties, most are local." Unsubstantiated claims about threats of violence have also been made, and "sharing information that isn't true creates fear" and can hurt the community. Bradner-Jacobs emphasizes that "telling the truth matters" and that it protects everyone, allowing Democrats and Republicans to peacefully speak and protest without fear. Telling the truth matters, as it keeps the community safe.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on misinformation about protests and threats of violence, emphasizing community safety, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic. It also references local political bodies, making Local Government a secondary fit, and touches on partisan dynamics, relating to Race & Diversity.

title: Strained blue lines - Police battle mental health challenges along with crime
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content: Capt. Kenneth Rainey of the Sarasota Police Department noted that peer support programs can help eliminate stigmas associated with mental health, saying "It never got the attention it deserved," and "Nobody knows officers better than their coworkers and fellow employees. We're really trying to eliminate the stigmas associated with mental health saying that its OK to ask for help." Laramie County Sheriff Brian Kozak stated that staffing shortages take a toll on personnel's morale and mental health, saying "The pressures of the job from working so many hours are catching up to them," and recently, "Just a few weeks ago, we had a deputy who was stabbed." Efforts to address mental health include expanding peer support programs, with Kozak saying "We're looking to expand that," and creating a new culture where "It's all about affecting a new culture within an organization that it is OK to say you are not ok," as Rainey put it. Capt. John Bollinger emphasized the need for "frequent reminders that seeking help is not a sign of weakness," and noted that negative views of police, fueled by "bad actions of a few police officers," can impact officers' morale, saying "Too many citizens nationwide believe police officers are generally bad people," and "It's challenging to put on a police uniform and feel or just assume there is just disdain for you just as a result of your profession." However, "Individuals know in their own hearts that the great majority of police get involved because they want to help people," Bollinger added, and Capt. Bollinger also said "I am old school, 43 years on the job, so this was difficult for me to learn, but being in a command position changes your perspective when looking out for the welfare of your people." The Eau Claire Community Foundation's effort to reimburse local law enforcement officers for mental health expenses states that "The fund was recently established to reimburse local law enforcement personnel for mental health expenses not covered by their health insurance; grants will be paid directly to the Eau Claire County Sheriff's Department (since we can't make grants to individuals) and applied to their requests for reimbursement."

title: Maryland man gets 8 years in crossbow killing of girlfriend
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Cecil County Circuit Court Administrative Judge Brenda A. Sexton sentenced Jeffrey Allen Lander to eight years in prison for fatally shooting his girlfriend, Judy Elizabeth Gee, with a crossbow arrow, remarking that Lander's "conduct was heinous," and noting his "lack of remorse or acceptance of responsibility for Gee's death." Lander had told investigators that the incident started when "She was kicking me in the knee. It was a rude awakening. I woke up angry." Detectives testified that they believed Lander shot Gee in the "heat of the moment" during an argument. Lander's lawyer, Jason Ricke, described the shooting as "a tragic accident — nothing more. It is not a murder. It is not a crime." Lander was convicted of involuntary manslaughter but acquitted of murder and assault.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and court proceedings, which are matters of public safety and law enforcement.

title: County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe
author: Staff Writer
content: Talbot County has purchased an AeroFit testing system to ensure the safety of its firefighters and emergency responders. The system provides precise, OSHA-compliant fit tests for N95 respirators and other protective gear. According to Jimmy Eason, President of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire & Rescue Association, "With the county's support, this system ensures that every responder, whether volunteer, law enforcement, or emergency services staff, can be confident their protective equipment will keep them safe." The county's investment in the AeroFit system is part of its ongoing efforts to prioritize the safety of both residents and first responders, with council President Chuck Callahan stating that it's "about taking care of the people who take care of us."

title: Investigation continues after children die in Perryville home
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: An investigation into the "circumstances surrounding the suspicious deaths" of two children continued on Tuesday night after they were found unresponsive inside their Perryville home, according to the Maryland State Police. Troopers responded to the residence to assist with the "cardiac arrest of two juveniles," where paramedics were "attempting emergency medical care." The preliminary investigation, as outlined by an MSP spokesperson, indicates that the sister came home and found both children unconscious, and "the two juveniles were brother and sister living in the house with their mother." "There was no indication of violence in the area surrounding the location where the juveniles were found." A search warrant was obtained, and "Crime scene technicians from the Maryland State Police processed the area and a search of the premises was conducted," the spokesperson reported.

title: Jury acquits man of all charges in fatal shooting
author: Carl Hamilton and Lilly Howard cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Donald Raymond Snyder Jr.'s defense lawyers maintained that he shot Christopher Cimorose in self-defense after Cimorose threatened, "I'm going to kill you, (expletive)," while a metal pipe rested on his lap. Cecil County State's Attorney James Dellmyer, however, argued that Snyder gunned down Cimorose "in cold blood," saying "Thirteen seconds, in real time, you are going to see the intentional, premeditated killing of Mr. Cimorose," and "This is evidence of first-degree murder. Chris (Cimorose) didn't stand a chance. That gun was on him before he got out of the car," as Snyder was "briskly walking up" to the driver's side door. Dellmyer stressed, "You cannot start a fistfight and then shoot someone to death," and asked, "Is it reasonable to use deadly force?" Snyder's girlfriend, Michelle McCarthy, testified that she was ending their relationship, saying "I said, 'That's it. I'm done with you . . . I packed all my stuff in the car,"" and that Snyder punched Cimorose before shooting him, stating "I saw the punch. I saw everything." McCarthy's credibility was questioned by the defense, with Snyder's lawyer, Joshua Insley, highlighting that she initially didn't mention Snyder throwing a punch, admitting "I was covering a little bit for my boyfriend." Insley also asked McCarthy, "Ever smoke crack before," and noted that Cimorose had various drugs in his system, as well as referencing the object Cimorose possessed, accusing investigators of "sugar-coating" its description. When Insley asked McCarthy if her cooperation was related to dismissing drug cases against her, she responded, "Drugs has nothing to do with this case," and Insley followed up by saying "I heard it makes you pretty wacky."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal trial and jury verdict, which pertains to law enforcement and public safety issues rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: Easton man killed in car crash in Anne Arundel County
author: Konner Metz
content: An Easton man, Jose Garcia Tovar, 22, was killed in a car crash in Anne Arundel County on June 15. The crash occurred on Route 32 East just past the Telegraph Road overpass, where the Chevrolet Camaro left the road, hit the median guardrail, and stopped in the median, before becoming "engulfed in flames," according to police. Garcia Tovar was pronounced dead on the scene, while the 20-year-old Easton woman driving the car was transported to Shock Trauma for non-life-threatening injuries. title: Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December

content: The Rev. title: Queenstown man charged in Centreville shooting
author: Staff Writer
content: A 17-year-old male from Queenstown has been charged as an adult in connection with a November 22 shooting in Centreville, Maryland. The suspect, whose name has not been released, was arrested on January 3 at a residence in Queenstown. Police Chief Robert Hobbs said the suspect and the victim, an adult male, are related, and that the victim sustained "only superficial injuries" and was released from the hospital the same evening. The suspect is being held pending trial and faces charges including attempted second-degree murder and use of a firearm during a felony or violent crime. Hobbs confirmed that a handgun was seized as evidence during a search of the residence.

title: Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A 17-year-old female suspect, not enrolled in the Talbot County Public Schools system, has been charged with "making a threat of mass violence" after a bomb threat forced an evacuation at Easton High School. According to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, the caller "advised that there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up" and then "re-contacted the front desk staff a few minutes later and asked when dismissal was." Sheriff Joe Gamble praised the responders, saying "I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat." Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello also thanked staff and first responders, stating "I want to offer my sincere thanks to the teachers and the staff, and the first responders who attended the bomb threat today at Easton High School... You all were professional in caring for our children and put them first. In this day and age, you cannot be too careful." The sheriff's office noted that they "will be seeking additional charges if applicable." Gamble also commended the teachers and staff, saying "The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. We are so fortunate to have such dedicated professionals in our community who work very hard to keep our children safe."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a bomb threat at a high school and the police response, charging a suspect and detailing safety procedures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Investigators looking into fatal crash in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content: The Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General is investigating a fatal crash in Easton that occurred after an attempted traffic stop and pursuit on Monday evening. Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office attempted to stop a vehicle on westbound Route 50, but the driver did not comply and continued driving, leading to a pursuit that ended with the vehicle crashing into a tree. Four people were in the vehicle, and all were injured, with one adult woman later pronounced dead at the hospital. "The involved officers were equipped with body-worn cameras," according to the report. The investigation is ongoing, and those with information are asked to contact 410-576-7070 or email IID@oag.state.md.us.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police pursuit and fatal crash being investigated by state authorities, which falls squarely under public safety matters.

title: Caroline commissioners discuss plan for public safety after Ridgely police suspension
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: The Commissioners of Caroline County discussed a plan to maintain public safety in Ridgely after the suspension of the Ridgely Police Department. The county will temporarily partner with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office to provide law enforcement services, with the sheriff's office working one five-hour shift daily, seven days a week. "The Caroline County Sheriff's Office will lead half of 911 dispatch calls for the town, and every other call will go to the Maryland State Police," according to the commission. Sheriff Donald Baker will also secure warrants, firearms, and the front door of the Ridgely Police Department. The Ridgely police department was suspended with pay on March 13 pending an investigation by the Office of the Maryland State Prosecutor.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how local officials are arranging law‑enforcement coverage after the police department suspension, centering on maintaining public safety for the community.

title: Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn
author: Konner Metz
content: Jordan Cabrera, 20, of Trappe, Maryland, was arrested on March 2 and charged with possessing and distributing child pornography. Cabrera's ex-girlfriend, who was underage during their relationship from 2021 to 2023, filed the charges, stating that he obtained nude photos from her and distributed them on messaging apps, including Telegram, as well as on Instagram and Twitter. She wrote, "I was a minor in every nude photo and video." Cabrera was initially held without bond before posting $1,500 bond on March 3, and a preliminary hearing is set for March 31.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a criminal charge for child pornography, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, education, health, or other categories.

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content: Attorney General Anthony Brown stated that the audit validated concerns that bias may have affected death investigations in Maryland, saying "Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards." The audit, which reclassified 36 out of 87 cases from accidental or natural to homicide, was prompted in part by controversy surrounding former Medical Examiner Dr. David Fowler's testimony in the Derek Chauvin trial, where he cited "excited delirium" as a possible cause of George Floyd's death. Gov. Wes Moore noted that "This audit marks the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration." ACLU of Maryland senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar said, "This 70-page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth. That the entire system has been complicit in making police-involved deaths seem inevitable."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police‑involved death, an audit of medical examiner rulings, and policy reforms related to law‑enforcement custody, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Easton Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh said, "Every storm is different and unique," and feels that the town is prepared for the upcoming snow. A major winter storm is expected to bring snow and ice "from the Central Plains to the Mid-Atlantic" this weekend. Van Emburgh noted that the town is preparing by putting plows on trucks and loading salt, and "And we have equipment that we're placing around town that we'll use to address alleys and some of the tighter spots that we plow." Residents are advised to take precautions, such as having a "supply of fresh water in case the power goes out and you're on well water and therefore you rely on the power for your water source," as suggested by Dorchester County Emergency Management Division Director Jimmy Windsor. Van Emburgh also requested that residents not park on main streets, as "When people park on the streets, we have to plow around the cars and sometimes that can — depending on how much snow we get — that can get tricky and then we plow the cars in." Additionally, Van Emburgh advised residents to clear snow from sidewalks by plowing it away from the street, saying "Because we then plow it back onto the sidewalk... It's just a battle. (Residents) plow it onto the street. We plow it back onto the sidewalk. And they get mad at us" and "Some properties don't have yards... But if you plow it out in the street, it's just going to get pushed back onto the sidewalk. So we ask that everything moves away from the center of the street."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on snow‑storm preparedness, emergency management, road plowing, and safety advisories from county and town officials, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

Debbie Gardner, Talbot County Public Schools Communications Director

title: Bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content: Bob Spanburgh, Maryland ABATE's board chairman, said "It's been 32 years this year to no avail," but the group continues to push for a bill that would make wearing a helmet optional, named in honor of Gary "Pappy" Boward. Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett and Washington) believes "we as government do better when we educate people, (rather) than legislating something," and supports giving people the choice to wear a helmet. Spanburgh was turned into an activist by ABATE, recalling "At the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me (was), 'You got to register to vote. It's very important in this organization,'" and "That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time." Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Caroline, Cecil, Kent and Queen Anne's) praised ABATE, saying "They're diehards for what they believe in," and "Thank God they do. They don't let go of this stuff." Gene Ransom, CEO of MedChi, argued that not wearing a helmet "ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money." Ken Eaton, Maryland ABATE's executive director, vowed to continue pushing the bill, saying "If I don't do it, who else is going to do it?" Meanwhile, Spanburgh noted "We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we're nuts, probably," and Sen. Jill Carter (D-Baltimore City) said "I don't agree with them that they shouldn't wear a helmet, but I do agree about the civil liberty issue." The bill is scheduled for a hearing before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee. "But we keep introducing it," Spanburgh said, and proponents vow they won't stop trying if it's unsuccessful.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state helmet law, its safety implications, and legislative efforts to change it, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Easton woman charged with placing swastikas on political signs
author: Konner Metz
content: Frank Gunsallus stated that "these types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign" and that "This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention." Rabbi Fred Scherlinder Dobb expressed that he was "disappointed" and noted that while "I would say Easton and Talbot County are mostly a wonderful refuge from some of that national division," "But sadly, and maybe inevitably, pieces of that creep in." The stickers were found on Gunsallus signs in "high-minority areas," and a town official reported that removing the stickers caused "permanent damage" to the signs, "rendering them unusable." Police found a "large roll of matching swastika stickers" in Cristaudo's residence. Dobb added that "Full-on continental devastation and genocide — which is the ultimate Nazi legacy — needs to be reserved for issues far greater than Town Council."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a hate‑motivated vandalism case involving police charges, making it primarily a public safety/crime story, with secondary relevance to race/diversity and local government.

title: Three graduate from Caroline County's Problem Solving Court
author: Tom McCall
content: Judge Heather Price presided over the graduation of three women from the Caroline County Problem Solving Court, stating, "Being the problem solving court judge is sometimes a very difficult job, but it is also one of the most gratifying parts of the job. You will hear some success stories today," and adding, "It is an achievement and we are sending our graduates back out into the world to do good things." Problem Solving Coordinator Michelle Bethke explained that the program "employs science-based best practices to provide a pathway to sobriety for participants with diagnosed substance use disorders utilizing a combination of therapy, counseling, mentoring, encouragement and discipline when necessary." Graduates shared their personal stories, with Whiteley, a 2022 graduate and keynote speaker, saying, "I am a recovering addict and alumni from the Problem Solving Court. The definition of recovery is the process of change for which individuals improve their health and wellness, live a self-directed life and strive," and "The mindset and thinking pattern I once had, I needed to give up in order to change. Today I am a strong worthy loving and lovable woman, mother and friend." Other graduates expressed gratitude, with Nichole Meredith stating, "My addiction had taken everything that I ever loved away from me... This program has saved my life. I have full custody of my kids now. My family and friends can depend on me," Samantha Mitchell saying, "Drug court has given me the resources I need when I need people," and Carole Rawding saying, "I am just glad I accepted this program."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a court‑based program addressing substance use disorder and recidivism, featuring judges, sheriffs, and police officials, which aligns most closely with public safety. Health is a secondary theme due to the focus on addiction treatment, and local government is relevant because county officials participated.

title: Talbot County Sheriff's Office to place cameras in patrol cars
author: Konner Metz
content: Sheriff Joe Gamble stated that a state investigation into a fatal police-involved chase last year "definitely played a role in" the decision to install in-car cameras, saying "It definitely played a role in it." The cameras will increase transparency and aid in evidence gathering, Gamble said, adding that they "protects our deputies in the sense that, this is what they did," and "if there's allegations they did something else, it's on footage." Other Eastern Shore sheriffs agree, with Queen Anne's Sheriff Gary Hofmann saying "It's been extremely beneficial for us to avoid any type of complaints or allegations," and Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker stating "I think that they make a good cop better," and "they limit false reports."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the sheriff's office installing in‑car cameras to improve transparency and evidence gathering, which directly relates to public safety and law‑enforcement operations.

title: 4 plead guilty to varying misdemeanors in 2024 Kohl's incident
author: Konner Metz
content: Four individuals pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges related to a 2024 incident in an Easton Kohl's parking lot. Raven Todd, 24, pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment and loaded handgun in vehicle charges, stating he was assaulted by three others, including being hit with a beer bottle and punched multiple times. Judge Philip Cronan sentenced Todd to two years probation and community service, with 212 days credited for time served. The three others - Tucker Eason, Blake Dorman, and Navelie White - pleaded guilty to assault charges and received sentences they are currently serving. "Video showed the attack during which Todd fired his gun after the assault ended with people fleeing the area," according to the Easton Police Department.

title: Police arrest man on charges in overdose
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: A Henderson man, Justin A. Bodman, 35, was arrested on September 28, 2023, on charges related to an overdose death in Easton in September 2022. Bodman is charged with manslaughter, narcotic distribution, and other related counts. According to police, Bodman and Elina Lazarieva, 23, of Easton, obtained heroin in Delaware and delivered it to 28-year-old Cristian Gonzales, who later overdosed. Lazarieva was previously arrested on August 2 on similar charges and is scheduled for a jury trial in early January. Both Bodman and Lazarieva are being held at the Talbot County Detention Center, although Lazarieva was released on bond on September 12.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police arrest and criminal charges related to an overdose death, making it primarily a public safety/crime story rather than a health-focused piece.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat
content: Chase Armington, past president of Lodge 108 and current Queen Anne's County deputy, began the ceremony saying, "Tonight, we gather to honor our fallen heroes... So that we may continue on the path they have now paved." Sue Nickerson, whose son was killed in 2001, stated, "The FOP from QAC started [this event] and they will always have it on February 13th... It means a lot. It really does. QAC is willing to step up, and support the families, and acknowledge the jobs that our law enforcement, our firefighters, and our EMTs have done." Queen Anne's County State's Attorney, Lance Richardson, discussed stoicism, saying, "The heroes we celebrate tonight were tragically taken from us... So, tonight, we honor those who gave the ultimate sacrifice, their lives, so we could go on living our lives in peace and safety." The ceremony honored ten fallen heroes, including "Buck" Clough and "Dougie" Thomas, with a radio transmission stating, "Today we honor the memory and pay tribute to those who greatly served and protected QAC and the State of Maryland." Pastor Rev. Karen Handy closed with a prayer, "Lord, you gave them the gift of courage of serving others... Lord, we lift up and thank you for each of these persons."

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community memorial honoring fallen police, fire, and EMS personnel, which is directly related to public safety and first‑responder activities.

title: ‘High-risk targets’: New normal at churches, houses of worship after deadly attacks
author: Mike Sunnucks
content: Security experts and law enforcement officials are advising houses of worship to be proactive about security due to a rise in violent incidents, with 57% of American Jews saying they "believe that antisemitism is now a normal Jewish experience." Dan Skoczylas, vice president of CLS Background Investigations, said "All of the houses of worship should consider themselves to be high-risk targets at this point," and noted that some are considering metal detectors and increased staffing. The Lee County Sheriff's Office "continues to maintain vigilance and security" and conducts frequent area checks, with public information officer Julie Sin stating "We have hundreds of individual places of worship and religious centers within Lee County. Deputies are familiar with those in their patrol sectors and conduct frequent area checks — this is standard practice." Gene Petrino, CEO of Survival Response LLC, said some facilities are adjusting access points and adding security checkpoints, while Cathal Walsh of Guidepost Solutions suggested houses of worship look at entrances and exits for vulnerabilities. Temple B'nai Israel in Easton, Maryland, has implemented various security measures, including a gated parking area, magnetic locks, and security cameras, saying "We take security very seriously," due to "the considerable uptick of anti-Semitic threats violence." The Council on American-Islamic Relations has published a best practices guide for mosques, recommending a "vigilant" security staff that can give early warnings to congregants and approach suspicious individuals. Walsh also noted that there are federal grants available to help nonprofits and religious venues upgrade their security infrastructure, saying "You might receive the funding to install more security cameras." Gene Petrino emphasized the need for a visible deterrent while maintaining a welcoming environment, stating "The goal is a visible deterrent while maintaining a welcoming environment." Skoczylas cautioned that social media presents a challenge, saying "Social media is very touchy, it's the conduit of all things good and bad." Additionally, there have been incidents of "swatting," and law enforcement agencies are providing "threat assessment" and "criminal intelligence" to investigate threats.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on increased security, police patrols, and threat assessments at houses of worship following violent attacks, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety category.

content: Police in Queen Anne's County, Maryland, have arrested a suspect in a May 17 homicide in Chester. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family as they deal with this tragedy and senseless act." title: Debby's remnants bring flooding to the Shore
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Rescue Fire Company Chief Adam Pritchett stated, "We've gotten a report on email from Emergency Management. It's been minor flooding so far," and added, "I believe the high tides are expected to be tonight of concern for Cambridge. But as of right now, it's been minor flooding so far." The Town of Oxford warned residents that a 4.5-foot tide was predicted, noting "By comparison, this morning's high tide that resulted in flooding throughout the town registered as a 3.9-foot tide at the Cambridge marker. With a 4.5-foot tide, the Causeway area will be impassable for a period of time." Pritchett said his department was prepared, stating, "We pretty much stay at a ready pace for things like this because it's becoming more normal all the time now with each storm that passes on," and "So we're kind of always ready for events like this. Have our equipment ready, checked out and so forth." The town also alerted residents with the message, "Please be aware that the NOAA prediction for this evening's high tide has changed significantly and is now anticipated to be 4.5 feet, which could produce major flooding."

title: Eclipse Tips
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content: The total solar eclipse on April 8 is expected to be one of the most traveled days in U.S. history, with 13 states from Texas to Maine able to see the moon completely block out the sun. To prepare, Destination Mansfield, an Ohio tourism group, has put together a list of eclipse tips, including being prepared for "overloaded internet networks, traffic congestion at popular viewing spots and having some cash in case payment networks are overwhelmed or disrupted." The group recommends filling up cars with gas and stocking up on food and other staple items. Many schools in the eclipse path will be closed on April 8, and police, fire departments, and hospitals may see increased volumes. The eclipse will be livestreamed online by NASA, the Exploratorium museum, and TimeandDate.com.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on safety-related advice for the upcoming eclipse, highlighting traffic congestion, overloaded networks, police, fire, and hospital preparedness, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

content: Roberto Ivan Zaldivar, Jr., 26, of Easton, was arrested on Oct. 6 for being on Colonel Richardson High School property as a registered sex offender. title: EMS team coordination astonishing
author: Staff Writer
content: Bill Mocarski called 911 during a snowstorm when his wife experienced a medical emergency. The 911 operator "listened, gave me directions, kept me calm and told me that the medical team was on its way." The EMS crew, accompanied by the Easton fire department, arrived within 15 minutes and handled the situation "quickly and efficiently." title: Firefighters battle blaze at auto salvage yard in Cambridge
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Firefighters responded to a third-alarm fire at Threesome Auto Salvage on Cordtown Road in Cambridge around noon on Tuesday. title: Man charged with threatening to blow up Delaware mall
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content: A 20-year-old man from Bear, Delaware, was charged after allegedly threatening to blow up the Christiana Mall on Saturday. Devin Cunningham was denied entry to the mall for wearing a ski mask, and then made "threatening statements to them about returning to the mall with a bomb, blowing it up, and killing everyone inside," according to police. title: Adams brings experience, potential K-9 to Greensboro Police Department
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Sgt. Jeff Adams chose the Greensboro Police Department due to his long-standing relationship with Police Chief Lenox Trams, stating "I was looking at different agencies but I reached out the chief. Chief and I go back to 2005 or 2006," and after a ride-along, he was "pretty much sold." Adams described himself as "easy going" and said "So what you see is what you get. I think Chief can attest to that, but I'm just laid back, professional, polite and kind." He is bringing his K-9, Mosley, who has been certified in tracking and narcotics, but lost a leg to cancer in 2023. According to Adams, "She's done everything," and "She nailed it" in recent training. Chief Trams expressed excitement, saying "We're really excited to be able to bring her on," but noted that the K-9 program needs to be approved by the Town Council as part of the budget cycle, stating "Hopefully we'll get the thumps up and then she can start working because we need one." Adams also praised the community, saying "I think the people here are very nice," and "They're genuine, and it just seem like a really good fit."

title: Talbot County Sheriffs' Office investigating another threat, threat not specific to TCPS
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble stated that the Talbot County Sheriff's Office is investigating a threat circulating on social media, which is a "clearly" photoshopped image targeting the 410 area code, not specifically Talbot County Public Schools (TCPS). The district is "closely monitoring the situation" and working with local authorities, with school operations continuing as normal. Gamble noted that other jurisdictions "have had 40 or 50 of these types of threats," saying, "It's happening all over our country where, for whatever reason, somebody is trying to disrupt school operations and put our kids in fear," and added, "This just seems like the thing to do these days for some reason."

title: Easton Man Gets 18 Years For Enticing Child For Sexual Activity
content: U.S. District Judge George L. Russell III sentenced Samuel Charles Hardeman, 55, of Easton, to 18 years in federal prison for attempting to coerce and entice a minor to engage in illicit sexual activity. The sentence was announced by United States Attorney for the District of Maryland Erek L. Barron, who commended the FBI and the Talbot County Sheriff's Office for their work in the investigation. The case was part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative to combat child sexual exploitation and abuse, which "marshals federal, state, and local resources to locate, apprehend, and prosecute individuals who sexually exploit children and to identify and rescue victims." For more information, visit justice.gov/psc and click on the "Resources" tab on the left of the page. Hardeman will be under lifetime supervised release after his prison term.

title: Sewage truck crash closes eastbound U.S. Route 50
author: TOM MCCALL
content: On Monday morning, an 18-wheel sewage truck crashed through a guardrail on eastbound U.S. Route 50 near Hiner's Lane, closing the lane. According to an official on the scene, "at least no one died." The truck veered off the road, slid over 100 yards into a wooded ravine, and tore through a front yard. Easton firefighters and State Patrol officers responded, and eastbound traffic was detoured off Route 50 to Longwoods Road. There was no odor of sewage at the site.

title: Students warned of 'imposters' with offers of 'DoorDash-style' marijuana deliveries
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content: State officials warn University of Delaware students and Newark residents of a fraudulent marijuana operation distributing flyers and business cards claiming to be associated with Fresh Cannabis, a licensed dispensary. One ad features a cartoon marijuana leaf character and reads, "UDEL-iver? Yes we do!" and "Quick delivery for on-campus students only! (DoorDash/Uber Eats Style!),". According to Jon Peterson, a spokesman for the Delaware Division of Alcohol & Tobacco Enforcement, "Delaware's adult-use marijuana marketplace includes strict regulations and testing standards designed to ensure consumer safety. Products sold through illegal channels bypass these safeguards and may contain dangerous contaminants such as mold, pesticides or heavy metals." Peterson also stated that "DATE's Marijuana Enforcement Unit is actively investigating this matter and encourages anyone with information about these fraudulent materials to come forward," and that tips can be sent to Cpl. Tristin Burris.

title: Delaware woman killed when falling tree hits SUV during storm
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content: A Delaware woman was killed and another injured when their SUV was hit by a falling tree near Wilmington during a thunderstorm on June 30. The incident occurred just after 10 p.m. in the westbound lane of Lancaster Pike, approaching Hedgerow Place in Newark. The passenger, Beverly Wolfe, 79, of Newark, died at the scene, while the 79-year-old male driver from Newark was hospitalized for serious injuries. State troopers are investigating and are asking witnesses to contact Master Cpl. J. Forester at 302-365-8485.

title: State Supreme Court hears arguments on police stops for cell phone use while driving
author: Konner Metz
content: The Maryland Supreme Court heard arguments in the case of State of Maryland v. Michael Eugene Stone, who was pulled over by police for "manipulate[ing] a cell phone that was attached to his windshield." Justice Brynja Booth expressed concern that accepting the state's position would mean "any time somebody touches a cell phone device, that would constitute reasonable suspicion." Stone's public defender, Douglas Nivens II, argued that "This is a case about Mr. Stone … reaching up to touch the screen of his cell phone mounted on his dashboard," and that "One touch being the grounds for a traffic stop is a bridge too far." The Appellate Court had previously ruled that "There is insufficient evidence in the record from which the trial court could properly conclude that the officers had reasonable suspicion to conduct a traffic stop." Nivens emphasized that "We don't want officers just stopping people at random because they have a hunch."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legal debate about police traffic stops for cell phone use, directly relating to public safety concerns about distracted driving and law enforcement practices.

title: Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Committee hosts a USO dance
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Bridget O'Brien, 2024 Miss Maryland, opened the USO dance at Easton Elks Lodge by singing the "Star Spangled Banner." Michael Feehley, chair of the 1622 Veterans Affairs Committee, stated, "We believe in taking care of veterans, the veterans that use services at Pleasant Day, whether it's just for two meals, whether it's for medications, whether it's to meet with medical people, whether it's transportation to their medical appointments, they're only funded for two days a week through (Veteran Affairs), we feel it's necessary to fund those guys for five days." Tom Carlson, a Vietnam veteran, noted that guests of all ages enjoyed the music, saying, "It wasn't just people in their 60s and 70s and 80s. There were a lot of people in their 20s and 30s, and they had a great time too," and "It's amazing that some of these youngsters really knew the music. They know our songs that we grew up with." Feehley encouraged attendees to thank veterans for their service, saying, "When you see that Army hat or the Coast Guard bumper sticker on the back of a car, or anything that says, 'Hey, I was in the service,' say, 'Thank you for your service,'" "Because that veteran, the person who wears that hat, or the person who drives that car, they gave an awful lot of themselves," and "They took time away from their families, away from home, in some but not all cases, they put themselves in danger, so you and I can do what we do today, and who are we not to give back to those people."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event organized to support disabled veterans, a group often associated with public safety and veteran affairs. While it involves local community involvement and fundraising, the primary focus on veteran support aligns best with the Public Safety category.

title: Easton airport runway closed for construction work
author: TOM MCCALL
content: Airport manager Micah Risher stated that "Runway 4/22 is closed. The Xs are out there as a reminder for pilots from the air. They can see them very clearly flashing, and they know not to land on the runway." The airport has taken additional safety measures, including disabling the instrument landing system, as Risher noted, "In addition, we have physically turned off the instrument landing system for Runway 4/22, so pilots cannot inadvertently receive the landing data." Risher also mentioned that "We have got some barricades out there. We have turned off other visual aids for that runway." Meanwhile, "We have a second runway, 15/33, that is still operational." The closure is part of the Airport Modernization Program and is expected to last until April 9, with intermittent closures thereafter.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a runway closure and safety measures at a local airport, emphasizing public safety concerns rather than broader governmental or economic issues.

title: Officials emphasize firework safety ahead of July 4
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Master Deputy State Fire Marshal Oliver Alkire advises residents to attend public fireworks shows, but for those who still want to set off fireworks themselves, he recommends buying within their county or area, saying, "If you are going to be using any fireworks, just to keep in mind that you should only be purchasing and using fireworks that you are buying within your county or your area," and adding, "... Anything that you can purchase at a roadside stand, I can assure you, has been inspected, or anywhere in any retail stores." Alkire also stresses safe handling, stating, "If you're going to light fireworks, only allow the adults to light the fireworks, only light one firework at a time, and also keep all children and pets away from fireworks." Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson recommends having a water hose nearby in case of a fire.

title: Woman killed, two others injured in Preston crash

content: A 30-year-old woman, Courtney Dunn of Salisbury, was killed in a two-vehicle crash in Preston on Tuesday. The crash occurred when a Chevrolet failed to stop at the intersection of Harmony Road and Grove Road and struck a southbound Ford. Two others, the driver of the Chevrolet and a 16-year-old passenger, were flown to hospitals in Salisbury and Baltimore for treatment. "The crash investigation is still ongoing and is being led by the Maryland State Police Crash Team," police said, adding that the findings will be sent to the Caroline County State's Attorney Office to determine if charges will be filed. content: The Ridgely Police Department, inactive for nearly 18 months, is still at the center of controversy in Caroline County. title: ‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Tina Kintop, EMS division chief, described the Talbot FiRST! peer support program, saying "The idea is that they can come from the bottom up, meaning that they will know who all the peer (team members) are," and " … They will be able to contact who they want to contact." County Manager Clay Stamp noted the need for better mental health support, stating "The things that we expose our 18-year-old kids to — that become EMTs or dispatchers or police officers — are horrendous," and "We have got to come up with a better way to arm these individuals to deal with these things in a healthy manner and to give them a support system." Former EMS Division Chief Matt Watkins praised the initiative, saying it's a step few communities have taken. Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan recalled the stigma around mental health, saying "You kind of feel like you're out there alone sometimes, and you need to talk to somebody," and assured first responders that "As long as we're up here, you guys are never ever going to get forgotten," "because you're our heroes in Talbot County, and we love you guys and you protect us."

title: Kyleigh remembered - Community rallies around family of girl killed in Christmas morning fire
author: Carl Hamilton; cahamilton@chespub.com

title: Multiple crashes at Easton intersection lead to resident concerns
author: Konner Metz
content: Residents Lydia Pinkney and Tony Ruffini expressed concerns about the intersection of Brookletts Avenue and South Aurora Street, with Ruffini stating, "You stand out here for about five, ten minutes, you'll see how fast people go." Pinkney worries for her safety and her daughter's, saying, "The speed limit's 25, and I know people are going more than 25... them running the red light or just going way too fast and clipping me and my daughter." The Easton Police Department announced that they have begun "targeted traffic enforcement" and adjusted the traffic light timing to lower the "chances of a collision if a driver attempts to beat a red light." Resident Lisa Stone noted that she has "seen so many near accidents at the intersections, particularly Hanson and Brookletts," but is pleased with the town's recent safety measures, saying "I think that's a good improvement." Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh explained that the added on-street parking lines will improve safety by giving drivers "cues as to where they're supposed to be in the travel lanes," as previously it "looks like a wide-open raceway." As a nearby development is redeveloped, Ruffini expects South Aurora Street "will be a main road before you know it," while Stone hopes "it will just be an increase in traffic and not a decrease in safety," with the traffic impact study finding "minimal impact on the surrounding road network."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on recent traffic crashes, resident safety concerns, police enforcement, and town engineering actions, which align most closely with the Public Safety topic, while also involving local government decisions.

title: Trial begins for Cambridge man accused of murder, kidnapping of woman
author: Konner Metz
content: Kenneth Bradley's trial began with prosecutors presenting a case full of "rage, control, domestic violence" and a "toxic" relationship between Bradley and victim Tiyavauna Britt, according to Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard. Police charging documents described camera footage from the park showing "sounds of loud thuds ... consistent with forceful strikes" and a man "carrying and dragging" a woman's body to a vehicle. Defense attorney Matt Connell acknowledged Bradley's involvement in Britt's death, saying "He lost it. He hit her too hard, and she died," and urged the jury to "Hold him responsible for what he's really guilty of, not above and beyond that." Britt's mother, Linda Harris, testified emotionally, stating "She wouldn't miss anything," regarding her daughter's absence from family events. The defense objected to some audio evidence, with Connell stating "We are fine acknowledging that that was him in the video," and noting that "90% of the verbal communication occurred inside the vehicle," while also saying "it's possible I'm mistaken." The judge ruled it "quite likely" the court will allow the video's admission, describing some of the audio as "chilling" and noting a potential "reasonable expectation" for privacy was not a valid objection.
