title: Ridgley commissioners vote to continue MOU with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Ridgely commissioners voted unanimously to continue the town's memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office. Commissioner Brad Sears stated, "I think at this point we're to a point where we would entertain a motion to give the town authorization to meet with the county to negotiate any changes to the MOU and go from there." The decision came after discussing three options, including reverting to the sheriff's department regular patrol pattern, re-establishing an original police force estimated at $852,000 for the first year, as noted by Sears, who said, "I know last month we talked about three options, one completely going back to the sheriff's department regular patrol pattern... Second was to attempt to re-establish an original police force, and even that price was conservatively estimated at $852,000 for the first year if we could find the police officer." Sheriff Donald Baker supported the MOU, stating, "The sheriff's office is providing what is going to be a high quality of law enforcement in the town," and clarified that the town receives comprehensive services, saying, "The town going with the MOU with the sheriff's office, they get everything the sheriff's office has to provide as far as criminal investigations handled by a investigator or detective, as well as the sheriff's office is a member of the Caroline County Drug Task Force and we have two deputies assigned to that." Baker also addressed resident concerns, saying, "There was some confusion that this money is dumped right into the Sheriff's Office budget. That's not true," and explaining that the county bills the town based on usage, stating, "The county is billing the town based upon the usage. So, if we don't use something or there's money left over, the county does not bill it and it goes back to the town or the town keeps it and it's never filled." This decision follows an investigation by the Office of the State Prosecutor, which found no "sufficient evidence of criminal activity warranting further investigation or prosecution."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a town commission's decision regarding law enforcement services and funding, which directly pertains to public safety matters, while also involving local government actions.

title: Cambridge police investigating two weekend shootings
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Cambridge Police Department is investigating two shootings that occurred over the weekend. On Saturday, a 19-year-old Easton man was shot in the leg on Pine Street and transported to a hospital for non-life-threatening injuries. The victim told police he heard approximately five gunshots and saw a "black style SUV" in the area. On Sunday, police responded to shots fired at the 1000 block of Pine Street, finding shell casings but no victims. The department is seeking the community's help, saying "Anyone with information can anonymously call police at 410-228-3333."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police investigations of recent shootings, which directly pertains to public safety concerns.

title: Easton firefighters respond to blaze on Glebe Road
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Easton firefighters responded to a blaze on Glebe Road on Tuesday afternoon. No injuries were reported, according to first responders at the scene. The road was closed by over 10 emergency vehicles, including fire trucks from Easton, St. Michaels, and Cordova. "Smoke could be seen from a house at 366 Glebe Rd around 5 p.m. Tuesday," as crews worked to extinguish the fire, continuing their efforts as of 5:30 p.m. tending to the upper-story of the residential building.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire incident and the response by local fire departments, which falls squarely under public safety reporting.

title: Cambridge police arrest 15-year-old for allegedly shooting stepfather
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Cambridge police arrested a 15-year-old after the teen allegedly shot his stepfather in the face on Friday. The incident occurred in the 400 block of Skinners Court, where police found a male victim with a gunshot wound to the face. "This report may be updated," according to the Star Democrat report. The victim was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma for treatment, and the police department said a more detailed press release will be forthcoming with further details.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police response to a shooting and the arrest of a teen, which directly relates to public safety and crime reporting.

title: New patrolman to join EPD
content: Patrolman Christopher Mueller joined the Easton Police Department after graduating from Wor-Wic Community College's Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy on December 18, 2023. Mueller received awards for excellence in pistol marksmanship and academics during the ceremony. Deputy Chief Gregory Wright congratulated Mueller, saying, "We're excited to have Patrolman Mueller join our team. He's going to have a positive impact on our community." Mueller must complete a three-month field training program to satisfy full certification requirements as a Maryland law enforcement officer.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police department hiring a new patrolman and details police academy training, which directly relates to public safety matters.

title: Seaplane crashes into Harris Creek, pilot uninjured, state police say
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A seaplane crashed into Harris Creek on Thursday, according to Maryland State Police. The pilot, 62, was the sole occupant and did not sustain injuries, an MSP spokesperson said. The aircraft, an Aviat Husky, "experienced an unknown mechanical malfunction while approaching its designated water landing site," per MSP. State troopers and Maryland Natural Resources Police responded to the scene, and an independent towboat company, Towboat U.S., began towing the vessel out of the water around 7:00 p.m.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a seaplane crash and police response, which is a safety incident rather than sports, business, or cultural news.

title: Cambridge police investigating fatal shooting on Sunday
author: Konner Metz
content: Cambridge police are investigating a fatal shooting that occurred on Sunday. According to the Cambridge Police Department's Facebook post, a homicide occurred at the 900 block of Camelia Street, where a male victim sustained a gunshot wound to the head. First responders "attempted life-saving measures," but the victim was pronounced dead at the scene. The Cambridge Police Department stated that the investigation is underway and more updates will be provided.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police homicide investigation, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: PAUGH JOINS SHERIFF's OFFICE
content: Lt. George Paugh, former chief of the Greensboro Police Department, joined the Caroline County Sheriff's Office on Nov. 1 as commander of the criminal investigation division. Paugh previously served in the United States Marine Corps and spent 26 years with the Easton Police Department. Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker welcomed Paugh to the agency. Paugh's law enforcement career began with the town of Goldsboro, where he served for fewer than two years.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a law‑enforcement appointment within the county sheriff's office, which is primarily a public safety matter, though it also involves a local government agency.

title: Stolen delivery truck found burning on train tracks
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content: A stolen FedEx truck was found on fire along train tracks near Red Toad Road and Bethel Church Road on Sunday, Feb. 23. "Anyone with additional information regarding the incident is asked to call investigators at 410-386-3050," according to the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal. The truck was stolen from a nearby FedEx center in North East before being dumped and set on fire by an unknown arsonist, causing $200,000 in damages. Seven firefighters from the North East Volunteer Fire Company controlled the flames within 20 minutes after a CSX train operator discovered the fire.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a criminal incident involving arson and a stolen delivery truck, focusing on the fire response and investigation, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Reporting when rumors spread faster than facts
author: Staff Writer
content: A recent uptick in U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrests has posed a challenge for the Star Democrat newsroom as rumors spread quickly on social media. "Rumors circulated faster than verifiable facts, and many details remained inaccessible," according to the newsroom. To get a clearer picture, reporter Konner Metz conducted on-the-ground reporting in a small town on the Maryland-Delaware border, speaking with residents to learn how the community was grappling with immigration enforcement activity, as noted by Editor Wendy Weitzel: "Thanks, as always, for reading." The story is part of a larger, still unfolding narrative of ICE activity on the Eastern Shore.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses ICE arrests, rumors about law‑enforcement activity, and community impact, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Federalsburg carport fire causes estimated $125K in damage
author: Natalie Jones
content: A fire at a Federalsburg home on January 5 caused an estimated $125,000 in damages. The blaze originated in the attached carport and was discovered by the home's occupant. "Smoke alarms were present but did not activate," according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. Forty firefighters, primarily from the Denton Volunteer Fire Company, responded to the scene and controlled the fire in about 30 minutes. The cause of the fire is under investigation, and anyone with information is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a residential fire, the response of firefighters, and investigation by the fire marshal, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Hillsboro house fire results in $100K in damages
author: Staff Writer
content: A house fire in Hillsboro on Tuesday resulted in $100,000 in damages. A firefighter was injured and transported to a local medical center while combatting the blaze. The occupants, who were home at the time, escaped uninjured along with their multiple pet dogs after observing smoke and fire coming from an interior first floor bedroom. According to the fire marshal, it took 60 firefighters approximately one hour to control the fire. The cause is under investigation, and anyone with information is asked to call 410-822-7609.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a house fire, injuries to a firefighter, and a call for public information, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Man killed after shooting at Baltimore County police
content: A man was killed after shooting at Baltimore County police officers who were responding to a domestic disturbance call at a Parkville home on Friday. As officers approached the home, "a man opened the door and started firing at them," investigators said. At least three officers fired back, and the man was found dead outside with a handgun near his body. A woman was also found fatally wounded inside the home. No officers were injured, according to authorities. The Attorney General's Office is investigating the shootings, noting that the officers were wearing body cameras.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police shooting and homicide, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Bills' Miller facing arrest for assault
content: Buffalo Bills linebacker Von Miller is facing arrest for allegedly assaulting a pregnant person in Dallas. According to police, Miller got into a verbal argument with the victim, who is pregnant, and assaulted them during a "major disturbance" at a home on Wednesday. Miller left the scene before police arrived, and the victim was treated for minor injuries. An arrest warrant has been issued for Miller, 34.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on an alleged assault and arrest warrant, which is a public safety/crime matter, even though it involves a sports figure.

title: Lightning strike causes house fire in Toddville
author: Konner Metz
content: A house on Toddville Road caught on fire Saturday night after being struck by lightning, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The fire began in the living room and was discovered by an occupant around 9:30 p.m. Firefighters from the Lakes & Straits Volunteer Fire Company responded and controlled the blaze within 20 minutes. No injuries were reported, but damages are estimated at $35,000.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a lightning‑induced house fire and the response of fire crews, which falls under public safety incidents.

title: Severe thunderstorm causes 'numerous' power outages
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A severe thunderstorm that lasted about 30 minutes on Friday evening caused numerous power outages across the Mid-Shore. Easton Utilities said "Crews are responding to numerous power outages scattered across our service territory." Delmarva Power reported over 7,500 customers were without power in the Salisbury area. APG Chesapeake Regional President Orestes Baez described traffic on Ocean Gateway as "snarled as weekend drivers were not sure how to navigate the waves of wind and rain." The storm brought wind gusts of up to 80 miles per hour and hail, according to the National Weather Service.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a severe thunderstorm causing power outages, traffic disruptions, and emergency response, which are matters of public safety rather than broader environmental or governmental policy.

title: Talbot County man convicted of sexually assaulting a child
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Kevin Halmiton Manning, 34, of Talbot County was convicted of sexually assaulting a 3-year-old child after pleading guilty to 10 counts in two cases. Manning pleaded guilty to a felony third-degree sex offense in the first case and various charges related to witness intimidation and violating a protective order against the child's mother in the second case. The investigation was conducted by the Easton Police Department, Talbot County Department of Social Services, and the Talbot County State's Attorney's Office, and was prosecuted by Deputy State's Attorney Chelsea Endzel. Sentencing is scheduled for July 24.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal conviction for sexual assault, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe
author: Konner Metz
content: Police are investigating a serious rollover crash that occurred outside Trappe on Tuesday at around 4:30 a.m. near Chloras Point Road and Claylands Road. The vehicle rolled over multiple times, ejecting a passenger who sustained life-threatening injuries. The passenger was taken to the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton and later transferred to a shock trauma center in Baltimore. The 18-year-old driver, Ellis Newcomb, "refused treatment at the scene, according to the press release." The Talbot County Sheriff's Office is actively investigating the crash and is asking anyone with information to contact them at 410-822-1020.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a serious traffic crash, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: Charges dismissed for Ridgley man
author: Maggie Trovato
content: The Caroline County State's Attorney's Office has dismissed charges against 26-year-old Ridgely man Rhett Ritter. Ritter was indicted in January on charges including second-degree rape and sex offenses related to an alleged 2012 sexual assault case. Charges were dismissed on Feb. 22 due to "an absence of jurisdiction in the circuit court as presently charged." Ritter's defense attorney Chris Jennings stated at a bail review on Feb. 6 that Ritter was 14 years old at the time of the incident. The alleged incident occurred in January 2012 in Ridgely and involved another minor.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the dismissal of criminal charges by the State's Attorney's Office, which pertains to law enforcement and court matters, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Fire marshal investigating arson attempt at Ridgely trucking company
author: Konner Metz
content: The Office of the State Fire Marshal is investigating an arson attempt at Murphy Transport, a Ridgely trucking company. The owner noticed significant fire damage to the interior of one truck on Monday morning. "He later discovered other vehicles had also been targeted," according to the fire marshal's release. The damages are estimated at $100,000. The fire marshal's office is leading the investigation and is asking anyone with information to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire marshal investigation of an arson attempt, which is primarily a public safety issue involving emergency services and crime investigation.

title: Ignited fuel vapors cause fire at Dave's Riverside Garage
author: Maggie Trovato
content: A two-alarm fire occurred at Dave's Riverside Garage Inc. in Queen Anne on Monday afternoon, caused by ignited fuel vapors during mechanical work. The fire, discovered by an employee, took 69 firefighters an hour and 25 minutes to control, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The blaze started inside the garage, under a vehicle, resulting in an estimated loss of $750,000. Fortunately, "there were no injuries or deaths resulting from the blaze," the Office of the State Fire Marshal reported. The Cordova Volunteer Fire Department was the primary responding fire department.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fire incident, emergency response, and safety outcomes, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: CHIEF OF POLICE POSITION TOWN OF GREENSBORO
content: The Town of Greensboro is accepting applications for a Chief of Police position. The ideal candidate is described as "results oriented, has a great attitude, works efficiently, shows a record of success, has a passion for public service and wants to work in a team environment." The successful candidate will have excellent leadership and decision-making skills and be proficient in writing reports and handling paperwork. Minimum qualifications include being MPCTC certified, a US citizen, and having at least 10 years of administrative and senior command experience in law enforcement. The Town offers a competitive salary and a generous benefit package, including Maryland State Retirement.

llm_classification.explanation: The article advertises a Chief of Police position, directly relating to law enforcement and public safety functions, making Public Safety the most appropriate category.

title: People can get vicious
author: Staff Writer
content: Catherine Nobles, writing to the Star Democrat, expressed her disappointment with the verbal and physical aggression she witnessed while working at a campaign event, stating that people can get "vicious." During her time there, she was personally called a Nazi and heard the phrase "You are all sick." Others were also subjected to abuse, including being spat at, cursed at, and having objects thrown at them, with one sign holder having a cup of coffee thrown at him. Nobles witnessed a woman in her 70s give a Trump sign the middle finger, describing the behavior as "not very mature." Two ladies at the event even felt threatened enough to consider calling the police.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes verbal and physical threats and harassment at a public event, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Here is a summary of the public safety news story in 3-6 sentences:

Diego Albarado Lopez, 31, of St. Michaels was sentenced to 3 years and 90 days in jail for stalking, harassment, and trespassing as a peeping Tom. Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman handed down the sentence on October 18. Lopez was found guilty of charges stemming from a April 12 incident captured on surveillance footage, which showed him walking toward a bedroom window and "holding his hands near his groin area," according to charging documents. Lopez had previously been convicted of being a peeping Tom and trespassing in 2022 and was sentenced to 4.5 months in jail and three years of supervised probation. After his release, Lopez will be placed on three years of supervised probation and required to complete mental health and alcohol treatment.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and police involvement, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Bay Bridge to hold traffic temporarily today
author: Staff Writer
content: The Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) is temporarily holding traffic at the Bay Bridge for 15-30 minutes between 11 a.m. and noon "out of an abundance of caution" as the M/V Dali, escorted by four tugs, passes beneath the bridge. According to the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff, "undue traffic congestion is not anticipated on the east side of the bridge." Authorities are closing the bridge to avoid the risk of motorists driving over the Bay to look at the ship, which was involved in the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore. Travelers can contact 1-877-BAYSPAN or follow the MDTA on X/Twitter for real-time updates.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a temporary traffic hold on the Bay Bridge for safety reasons, involving the Maryland Transportation Authority, Coast Guard, and sheriff's office, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Suspect charged in Sunday Federalsburg shooting
content: Thomas Barr, 51, of Federalsburg, has been charged with attempted murder after a trespassing dispute early Sunday morning. According to Caroline Sheriff Donald Baker, Barr "fired two rifle rounds at the victim striking him in the chest." The victim, Gregory Hobbs, was transported to hospital after being shot. Barr was arrested and charged with multiple counts, including attempted second-degree murder and using a firearm during the commission of a felony. He is being held without bond pending trial.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident (a shooting) and the subsequent police response and charges, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Police investigating weekend shooting in Ridgely
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Caroline County Sheriff's Office is investigating a non-fatal shooting at the Daysprings Townhomes in Ridgely that occurred on Saturday night around 8:25 p.m. An adult male was found with a gunshot wound to the hand and was transported to a hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The Maryland State Police crime scene unit responded "to collect and preserve physical evidence in support of the investigation." The county's Criminal Investigations Division is conducting the investigation, and no suspect has been identified. Anyone with information can contact authorities at (410) 479-2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police investigation of a local shooting incident, which directly pertains to public safety concerns.

title: How one Mid-Shore town plans to weather future storms
author: Staff Writer
content: The issue of flooding has repeatedly affected coastal communities, with major roads washed out by stormwater and businesses protecting their merchandise from surge. "Having spent my career in coastal communities, there is one issue I have covered again and again. Flooding has affected every community I have worked in — a major road washed out by stormwater or a business protecting its merchandise from knee-high surge," the author noted. Mid-Shore towns are seeking solutions to better weather large storms.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses flooding impacts on communities and the need for solutions, focusing on safety hazards and protective measures, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

title: Police seeking information in Bay Bridge crash
author: Staff Writer
content: Maryland Transportation Authority Police are investigating a 23-vehicle crash on the westbound Bay Bridge on January 27. Investigators believe a blue 2018 Honda Civic sedan was being driven at high speeds and erratically prior to the crash and "may have contributed to the crash." Anyone who witnessed the blue Honda Civic traveling on westbound US-50 near the Bay Bridge between 7:30 and 7:45 a.m. on January 27 is asked to call the MDTA Police at 443-454-8703. The reconstruction is a "detailed process that typically takes months to complete" and potential charges are pending the conclusion of the investigation, according to police.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a major traffic crash, focusing on safety, witness assistance, and law enforcement actions, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department marks 100 years with parade Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content: Jesse Gottleib, president of the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department, noted that many small fire companies don't reach 100 years due to "not only funding, but more so because of lack of participation, lack of volunteers for the department." The department's success is attributed to community support, with Gottleib saying, "We would've never thought it," and "And I think the reason is because people in this side of St. Michaels down, they realize that we're gonna be there when they need it." His mother, Linda Gottleib, the department's secretary, hopes the junior firefighters competition will inspire kids to join, saying "It might help them to say, 'I wanna join.'" Jesse Gottleib recalled ditching a baseball game to watch the fire trucks pull out, saying "First game that we had down here at Tilghman school, the fire siren went off," and "And (my mom) and my dad were standing there and were like, 'Is he leaving?' And I ran across the field to go to the fence." The department is honoring longtime volunteers, including Dewayne Stewart and Billy Lednum, with Jesse Gottleib stating "You'll see a hurt in the fire department when those two are gone," and expressing appreciation for volunteers, saying "Their time is appreciated here."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the centennial celebration of a volunteer fire department, its role in emergency response, and community safety activities, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Eastern Shore fire companies aid areas affected by Hurricane Helene
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Eastern Shore fire companies have donated fire and EMS equipment to first responders in Tennessee affected by Hurricane Helene. Graham Norbury, chief of the Oxford Fire Company, said, "We do a lot of mutual aid to other departments in the area and elsewhere." Tim Kearns, president of Oxford Fire Company, explained that the volunteer system relies on mutual aid, stating, "It was important because the volunteer system works on mutual aid, so when someone is overwhelmed, we come to help," and "And that's what we did, only they're just a little farther away than most." The effort required significant coordination, with Kearns noting, "It took a lot of folks to coordinate and manhandle the transfer of this equipment, from the paperwork, insurances, transfer of titles and tags, to all of the logistics here, there and in between," and crediting Chief Engineer Stacy Dulin and Assistant Chief Engineers Mike Greenwak and Tom Bixler for ensuring the equipment was capable of the 500-mile trip, with Oxford Ferry loaning the heavy trailer. Multiple Maryland fire companies, including Oxford, Tilghman, and others, contributed to the effort.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fire companies providing emergency assistance and equipment after a hurricane, which directly relates to public safety services.

title: Democrats say no big changes to cannabis law
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content: Senate President Bill Ferguson stated that Democrats are considering "improvements" to Maryland's cannabis law, with "adjustments to the system that we passed last year," but not major changes. Ferguson said, "I think we're going to have a cannabis bill this year that sort of does some — I don't want to call it cleanup — but adjustments to the system that we passed last year," and added, "I don't think you'll see major changes to the program, but implementation adjustments." The law in question prohibits police from pulling over drivers solely due to the "odor" of marijuana, a provision criticized by Republicans like Sen. William Folden, who argued, "The irony is, if we see someone chugging a beer, police can pull them over," and that the law takes away probable cause when "there is a crime occurring, just because you're saying, well, you're not allowed to use your nose anymore." Del. Jheanelle Wilkins noted that the original law aimed to address "the harms of the past when it comes to criminalization of cannabis." Sen. Jack Bailey countered, "The public clearly wanted marijuana legalized, fine," but argued that requirements should not be done away with, saying "but we shouldn't do away with the requirements." Ferguson described the initial cannabis bill as complex, stating, "It was hugely complicated, lots of moving pieces for the cannabis bill last year."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on police powers and a law restricting vehicle searches based on marijuana odor, which directly relates to public safety and law enforcement issues.

title: Talbot County places burn ban
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: The Talbot County Council has enacted a 30-day burn ban due to dry conditions, prohibiting all "open-air burning," defined as "burning any material in the open or in a receptacle other than a furnace, … including use of fireworks, sparklers, or sparkling devices." According to Brian LeCates, county director of emergency services, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is "currently classifying Talbot County as having abnormally dry conditions." LeCates noted that the forecast shows no significant precipitation soon, stating "Looking at our weather forecast, we do not show any significant precipitation in the near future," and that "The Maryland Department of Natural Resources Forest Service has listed our area as highly susceptible to fire due to these conditions."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a county council's burn ban to prevent fire hazards, a measure primarily concerned with protecting residents from fire risk, fitting the Public Safety category, while also involving local government action.

title: After two deadly work zone crashes, Maryland officials press for change
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore enacted a set of protections for workers and their families that his administration describes as "a moral imperative." Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller stated, "The men and women in the construction industry place themselves in harm's way every day on the frontline of service," and "We saw it happen on March 22, 2023. And we saw it happen again on March 26, 2024. It's a moral imperative that we protect workers who provide critical service, public service for all of us." Steven Cook, a field maintenance technician, noted that "It happens more often than what people really think about and notice," and "You always got to have your head on a swivel with being out here on the highway … We're sitting ducks when we're out here on the job." State Highway Administrator William Pines said, "Most crashes are not accidents," and "In reality, they're very preventable. The majority of crashes that occur happen because of behaviors with drivers. So if we want to stop the root cause of most crashes, we've got to deal with driver behavior." Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson stated that the Fallen Transportation Workers Scholarship Program is intended to "protect others who are in a similarly dangerous situation," and Del. Ashanti Martinez noted that "When someone passes, particularly as the breadwinner or primary breadwinner of their family, it trickles down," affecting not just their immediate family, but also those they support in the community. Pines emphasized that "Our work zones are filled with mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, close friends and your neighbors... The highway is their office. Protecting them must be a priority for us."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on deadly work‑zone crashes, new safety legislation, and enforcement measures, which are core issues of public safety. It also involves state government actions, but safety concerns are the primary theme.

title: Easton officials weigh in on Complete Streets study, pedestrian safety
author: Konner Metz
content: Councilmember David Montgomery expressed concerns that prioritizing walking and biking would sacrifice the efficient flow of vehicular traffic, stating that many older residents in his ward aren't "interested in bicycling to downtown" and that "Automobile transportation is pretty much what everybody uses in order to get into the center of town." He added, "So I'm very concerned about our sacrificing the flow of single-occupancy vehicles, sacrificing it to other things, that for my ward, don't do any good at all by way of mobility." Heather Grant, executive director of Talbot Thrive, countered Montgomery's stance, saying "Some council members who mention the difficulties in traveling by car during school drop off and pick up should consider that if we make our streets safer for kids to walk and bike to school, we can reduce vehicle congestion."

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on pedestrian and bike safety initiatives and street design, which are primary public safety concerns, though it involves local government officials.

title: Mother charged in killing of daughter, 3, extradited back to Maryland
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Cecil County Circuit Court Judge Robert Sentman denied bail to Darrian Lynnelle Randle, 31, after Assistant State's Attorney Gavin Patashnick argued that the allegations against her were severe, stating, "The state cannot think of any (allegations) more heinous . . ." Patashnick also noted that Randle would have to return to Delaware after her trial in Maryland due to an agreement between the governors of the two states, saying, "Both governors in Delaware and Maryland signed the agreement. She must go back to Delaware immediately (after the adjudication of her Cecil County murder case)." According to court records, Randle allegedly told investigators that she asked her boyfriend, Cedrick Antoine Britten, to dispose of her daughter's body, and Britten "produced a map of where he believed that Randle may have disposed of" the body. Investigators found human remains "consistent with an emaciated child" inside a suitcase in a vacant lot, which were later identified as those of Nola Dinkins, the 3-year-old daughter of Randle.

title: Chester woman sentenced in 2024 multi-vehicle crash on Bay Bridge
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Gwendolyn Persina, 49, of Chester, was sentenced to 3 years in jail with all but 315 days suspended for a 2024 multi-vehicle crash on the Bay Bridge. "The state said the sentence fell within the recommended sentence range as calculated by the Maryland Sentencing Guidelines, which recommended a sentence ranging from six months to three years of active incarceration," according to the Office of the State's Attorney. Persina pleaded guilty via an Alford plea, acknowledging the state had sufficient evidence to find her guilty. The crash resulted in a victim's arm being severed and occurred when Persina, with a blood-alcohol content between 0.24 and 0.27, rear-ended another vehicle, causing a 23-vehicle chain reaction. Persina was also sentenced to 5 years of supervised probation and ordered to undergo mental health and alcohol evaluations.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and traffic accident, which are matters of public safety and law enforcement.

title: Pilot dies in plane crash near Easton
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: A 56-year-old pilot, Robert Eugene Merlini of Annapolis, died when his twin-engine Cessna 402 crashed into the Tred Avon River near Easton on Tuesday morning. Merlini reported an engine failure before the crash, which occurred around 9:30 a.m. "It's a sad day for not only the aviation community, but for the scientific community," said David Abrams, the communication director for the Maryland Department of the Environment. The plane was on a "ferry flight" and Merlini was relocating it, according to David Heidhausen, president at the University Research Foundation. The FAA and National Transportation Safety Board will investigate the crash.

title: Federalsburg carport fire causes estimated $125K in damage
author: Natalie Jones
content: A fire at a Federalsburg home on January 5 caused an estimated $125,000 in damages. The blaze originated in the attached carport of the one-story, wood-framed home on Iron Gate Road. "Smoke alarms were present but did not activate," according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. Forty firefighters, primarily from the Denton Volunteer Fire Company, responded and controlled the fire in about 30 minutes. The cause remains under investigation, and those with information are asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-822-7609.

title: 39 indicted, accused of drug-trafficking ring
author: Staff Writer
content: Thirty-nine people were indicted for their alleged involvement in a large-scale drug-trafficking ring on the Eastern Shore. The indictments followed a five-month investigation by Wicomico Narcotics, a collaborative effort between local, state, and federal law enforcement agencies. "Wicomico Narcotics received funding for this investigation from the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy and the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Forces," according to the report. The investigation yielded over 2,500 grams of suspected cocaine and nearly 30 grams of fentanyl, as well as 14 firearms and four vehicles. The operation involved more than two dozen law enforcement agencies, including the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Maryland State Police.

title: Mid-Shore organization pioneers a 'hub' of resources for victims of domestic violence
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Jeanne Yeager, executive director for Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence, stated that the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the organization's adoption of technology, saying "I was really mindful of coming out of COVID... So it normalized using technology, and I think there's no turning back." The organization developed a "hub" for resources, a Geographic Information System (GIS) program that provides a comprehensive dashboard for victims of domestic violence. Kazeem Anifowoshe, GIS senior data analyst, noted that traditional victim services often follow a established formula, saying "When people kind of think of victim services, there's kind of like a formula that a lot of people have been doing for 20 to 40 plus years at their organization that works for them," but the GIS program aims to innovate by "mapping things." Yeager expressed the organization's goal to expand the GIS Hub's adoption, stating "We ought to work with victims, and we're making this available. Let's see where we're going with it." According to Anifowoshe, the approach is centered on making resources more accessible, with the sentiment "But again, we're just trying to make things easier the best way we know how, by mapping things."

title: St. Michaels VFD places new engine into service
author: Mike Detmer; mdetmer@chespub.com
content: St. Michaels Volunteer Fire Department's new Engine 45, a 2023 E-One Cyclone, was put into service on July 27, replacing Engine 49 as the "first due" engine. According to St. Michaels VFD President Chris Thomas, the new engine features a larger water tank, a necessity in the rural area. "The department thanks the generous residents and businesses who helped make this purchase happen through their donations and support over the past few years," the fire department said in a statement. The $718,850 engine was funded through a combination of fundraising efforts and government funding. Thomas praised the department's fundraising efforts, saying, "I think that it is off the charts it's phenomenal," highlighting the success of events like barbecue chicken dinners and pit beef and pit turkey offerings.

title: 'Heartbroken': Delaware figure skaters, coach among those killed in D.C. plane, Black Hawk crash
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content: University of Delaware President Dennis Assanis said, "Our hearts go out to the families and friends of all of the victims of this horrific tragedy," after confirming that a coach and two young figure skaters with ties to the university were among the victims of the plane crash in Washington, D.C. The victims included Alexandr "Sasha" Kirsanov, a coach affiliated with UD's High Performance Training Center, and Sean Kay and Angela Yang, young members of the UD Figure Skating Club. Assanis noted that "Kirsanov and the skaters trained at the University's High Performance Training Center, which uses UD ice rink facilities and has been the training home for many years of multiple world-class skating champions and competitors," and that "The figure skating community is tight-knit, and many of our students and coaches have trained and competed alongside those who were lost." Delaware officials, including Gov. Matt Meyer and Sen. Chris Coons, expressed condolences, with Meyer saying "Here in Delaware, we're mourning the loss of former University of Delaware Figure Skating coach Sasha Kirsanov, as well as two youth skaters and their family members who were aboard AA5342," and Coons stating "Sasha Kirsanov, Sean Kay, and Angela Yang went to Wichita to pursue their passion for figure skating. It is a tragedy that none of them returned home to our state." Kirsanov's wife, Natalya Gudin, said "I lost everything," "I lost my husband, I lost my students, I lost my friends."

title: Cambridge woman pleads guilty to altering evidence in Sidetracked Saloon shooting
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Chadnee Harris, 33, of Cambridge, was sentenced to three years in prison, with 236 days to be served and the remainder suspended, after pleading guilty to altering physical evidence in the 2023 shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio Smith outside the Sidetracked Saloon in Easton. Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale said at Chase's plea hearing that Chase disposed of the handgun in the Choptank River after the shooting.

title: Four prison murders, but officials plead immunity
author: George F. Will
content: George F. Will reported that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit affirmed a district court's judgment that the family of John King, a murdered inmate, cannot sue to hold anyone at the prison responsible for his death due to "qualified immunity." The court held that there was no "clearly established law" forbidding the officials' actions, despite King's family asserting that his death resulted from prison officials' being "deliberately indifferent" to the danger he was in, and that officials had "supervisory liability." In the brutal murder, one inmate "stomped" on another's ribs, causing them to "pop." Judge James A. Wynn Jr. dissented, arguing that the officials' actions were an "atrocity" that occurred because of "deliberate indifference" and a "failure-to-protect" King from violence at the hands of other prisoners, violating the Eighth Amendment's proscription of "cruel and unusual punishments." According to the Supreme Court, "deliberate indifference" is established when a prison official "knew of a substantial risk" or "must have known about the risk," and "a prison official cannot hide behind an excuse that he was unaware of a risk, no matter how obvious." Will argued that granting qualified immunity in this case constitutes permission for lethal neglect, as it requires King's family to "pinpoint" with "specificity" a "precise" constitutional right violation, and the court claimed "there is no clearly established constitutional right to properly conducted security checks," allowing officials to not act "knowingly" to protect prisoners.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses prison violence, qualified immunity, and government accountability, which relate to public safety and criminal justice issues.

organizations: U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit

author: Staff Writer
content: Joseph Murphy agrees with the opinions in the article, "Why we cannot solve America's gun problem," stating that the recent Kansas City shooting highlights the need for a crucial conversation about gun safety. title: Rider trial postponed; bench warrant issued

content: Fred "Trey" Rider III's trial for arson, malicious destruction of property, and reckless endangerment was postponed, and a bench warrant was issued after he failed to appear in court due to being admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital. title: Body sits in Greensboro yard for hours due to traffic delay
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: On June 22, the Greensboro Police Department responded to a report of an unattended death at 110 Maple Ave. A male was found deceased on the stairs of his apartment and was pronounced dead at 2:06 p.m. after being moved to the front yard for further analysis. The body remained in the yard for hours due to a delay in transporting it to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore, caused by a 16-mile Bay Bridge backup. "The estimated time of arrival was initially an hour and a half, but due to a 16-mile Bay Bridge back-up, the transport was delayed and didn't arrive until 7 p.m.," the town statement said. The family declined offers to move the body back inside or into a body bag.

title: Police fatally shoot Cambridge man Thursday evening
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A Cambridge police officer fatally shot a "30-year-old Caucasian male from Cambridge" on Thursday evening after the man advanced on officers with a knife. According to the Cambridge Police Department, "Officers on scene attempted to deescalate the situation and have the subject drop the knife," but "The subject refused and advanced on officers. title: Juvenile services department to move detained girls, again
author: Steph Quinn; Capital News Service
content: Maryland's Department of Juvenile Services (DJS) plans to relocate detained girls to the Western Maryland Children's Center, with girls in long-term committed placement to join them "at a later date." The move aims to address issues highlighted in reports by the Juvenile Justice Monitoring Unit, including a staffer's comment that "They just treat these girls like chattel, moving them constantly from one place to another without thinking of how it will impact them," and a mental health therapist's statement that "They are just replicating the streets here, it's like survival every day" due to being "short-handed." DJS Secretary Vincent Schiraldi and advocates, including Moroney, agree that the institutional model is flawed, with DJS acknowledging that "It is the institutional model itself that is failing these young women" and Moroney stating "We would prefer that the girls not be incarcerated in the first place... But I guess if courts and the police cause kids to go to a jail-like situation, then having their own place is a better situation than being shoehorned into a boys' place." The reports also noted that girls were "ejected" from programs and faced challenges such as disrupted school, delayed medical care, and increased isolation, with one girl saying "It's so crazy here. It's so hard to concentrate in school because it is so loud, and loud noises are my trigger" and another stating "Me and my child feel threatened." JJMU wrote that relegating detained girls to a boys' facility "indicates a lack of appropriate planning and dedication of resources and arguably demonstrates a casual disregard for the well-being of girls in DJS custody."

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the state juvenile services department's handling of detained girls, facility moves, and related safety, mental health, and policy issues, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Stranded boater rescued by MSP aviation crew
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: A 22-year-old man was rescued by a Maryland State Police (MSP) aviation crew after his boat ran aground on a small island in Dorchester County on Thursday, October 12, 2023, early morning. MSP's Trooper 7 located the victim in his boat in a marshy area, but conditions were inaccessible by foot or boat. Trooper 2, with a Leonardo AW-139 helicopter, took over rescue operations and performed a hoist extraction using an air-lift rescue vest. "The success of the missions relies heavily on the cooperative efforts of local fire, rescue, EMS, law enforcement agencies and partners at the U.S. Coast Guard and the U.S. Park Police," according to the story, highlighting the collaboration involved in MSP Aviation Command's operations. The victim was ultimately transferred to ground paramedics and did not require treatment or transport.

title: No small feat
author: Maggie Trovato
content: CASA of the Mid-Shore Executive Director Robin Davenport distills a volunteer’s mission: “In a nutshell, we're saying, 'Be a sponge,'” adding, “Just go around and soak up every bit of information you can about the child. Wring the sponge out. Figure out what is important for us to be paying attention to and bringing to the court's attention,” while Coordinator Jane Crawford cautions that “Once people learn about the program and what's required, sometimes they need to think about it too because of that commitment.” Veteran volunteer Janet Healy calls the work “intensive” yet says, “And it just seemed like the right fit,” and celebrates “(Building relationships) with kids, with foster parents, with social workers,” while acknowledging, “It's hard when things don't work out the way you think they should, but it's also, on the other hand, very rewarding,” and cherishes feedback like, “That's very rewarding to get some of that feedback,” and “To see how well some of these kids are doing,” even though “and so there are a lot of things that we have to just keep track of and measure things in very small victories,” because “Because you do get very invested in these kids, but you know it really is temporary,” and “You have to keep that in the back of your mind all the time.” Davenport recalls that “It was a very tiny, tiny organization,” and “We, at that point, were only Talbot County,” before the 35-year-old nonprofit’s May “Voices of Hope” fundraiser, noting that CASAs have become “incredible touchstones” since “The CASA volunteers end up kind of being the one consistent adult in these children's lives,” and “Foster care is not a short turnaround usually. So it's been really exciting for us to see that the CASAs themselves are not only helping the judge, but they're actually really giving messages to the children that stick with them for years.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on court‑appointed special advocates (CASAs) who protect children at risk of abuse, neglect, or abandonment, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns about child welfare and protection.

title: Number of Cambridge homicides down in 2023
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Cambridge’s homicide count fell from seven in 2002 to three in 2023, a drop officials attribute to community-oriented policing and multi-agency collaboration. “It’s just started, but I think they're building a trust within the community that just did not exist before now,” Mayor Stephen Rideout said. State Police Lt. Kyle Clark emphasized joint operations: “We do concentrate on a lot of collaborative efforts with other units within the State Police and also allied agencies… And those are all tools that we use to combat the crime in any city.” Chief Justin Todd said CPD targets gangs “constantly harassating” residents and “everything and anything” is being done to prevent violence. “The partnership's been great with the Task Force and Maryland State Police… And that's what it's’s going to take,” he added. The city aims to continue “patting with a purpose” and “engage the community… to hopefully keep these numbers down,” Rideout said.

title: Lightning strike causes house fire in Toddville
author: Konner Metz
content: Lightning struck a Toddville home Saturday night, igniting a blaze reported around 9:30 p.m., according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. The Lakes & Straits Volunteer Fire Company controlled the fire in about 20 minutes after it started in the living room and was discovered by an occupant. No injuries were reported, and damages are estimated at $35,000.

title: 11-year-old killed in hit-and-run remembered in Elkton
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: “He had a bright smile. He hugged people. And he always showed students and teachers affection and gave them attention,” a Kenmore administrator recalled, while Rev. Moneira Hawkins told mourners, “Mesiah was only here 11 years, but he touched a lot of lives — more than most people do in 50 years. His spirit is still alive. He touched every one of you.” Teachers remembered “He was a wonderful big brother to his sister. He walked her to her classroom every day,” “I remember how friendly and outgoing he was,” and “I remember his fancy hairstyles,” with his sister adding, “I do his hair… He likes braids, straight backs — I guess you’d call them cornrows,” and classmates saying his dream job was “Professional NFL player.” After counselors reported “They were very busy all morning. They had a lot of questions,” one teacher comforted the children: “It’s OK to feel sad. It’s OK to cry. Take a moment,” while family recalled his dancing, his song “I Wish I Had You,” and stepdad saying, “He’s a natural. He has a way with words… That kid was special,” and dad concluded, “He was a bright light. When he walked into a room, he lit it up.”

title: QA, Kent approve regional jail agreement, Caroline not yet on board
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: Queen Anne’s and Kent counties have approved the final Mid-Shore Regional Detention Center agreement, while Caroline County has yet to commit. Caroline officials say they still lack precise cost figures, prompting Vice President Larry Porter to argue, “This decision is going to depend on the operational cost and I’m talking long range operational cost,” and suggest an independent evaluation. Queen Anne’s Commissioner Phil Dumenil counters that the state-backed regional plan “is a savings for all three counties,” and Kent leaders vow to renegotiate with Queen Anne’s alone if Caroline opts out.

title: American Legion Post 77 looking to jumpstart Hometown Heroes banner project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Joan Harris-Brooks, representing Blake-Blackston American Legion Post 77, won unanimous Easton Town Council approval for a Hometown Heroes banner program honoring Talbot County veterans, firefighters and officers along Ward 4 roads. Council support was emphatic: Ward 4’s Rev. Elmer Davis said, “I think that this is a great endeavor,” adding “(It's important) that we don't lose the memory of those persons who fought for our country. I believe it's our responsibility to help out with this project. Secondly, it doesn't cost the town a dime.” Harris-Brooks urged approval with, “It is our goal that you grant us approval. And we believe that if you grant us an approval, this will make a landmark for you as our councilmen,” and stressed education—“I think our children need to be aware… We still have young people still enlisted in the service. I will just very passionately say my uncle was a member of Post 77 … He gave his ultimate self serving.” After the vote, Post 77 Commander Victor Middleton closed with, “When people say thank you for your service, it really lifted me up just now to a higher level.”

title: Second fatal crash in three days prompts re-closure of Price Station Road crossover on U.S. 301
author: STAFF REPORT
content: After two fatal crashes in three days, the Maryland Department of Transportation State Highway Administration re-closed the Price Station Road median crossover on U.S. 301. The Church Hill Volunteer Fire Company confirmed coordination with SHA, stating, "As we did in July of 2024, the department leadership reached out to SHA to ensure emergency access would be available to Fire, EMS, and Police units responding to emergency calls on the east side of Route 301," and added, "We have been assured by SHA leadership that they intend to use the same process as before and that emergency access will be available." Sen. Steve Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, Caroline) also voiced support for the re-closure, stating, "Given the dangerous track record at this intersection — and now two fatal accidents in just three days — it is clear that further action is urgently needed."

title: North East mom, boyfriend charged in murder of toddler
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content: Maryland State Police charged Darrian Randle with beating her 3-year-old daughter Nola Dinkins to death and charged her boyfriend Cedrick Britten as an accessory. After the child stopped breathing, “Randle stated that once they returned to the residence she placed (the body) in a dark blue suitcase belonging to Britten,” then asked him to remove it. title: Severe thunderstorm causes 'numerous' power outages
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A severe 30-minute thunderstorm that swept the Mid-Shore Friday evening left thousands without power. Easton Utilities said in a Facebook post that "Crews are responding to numerous power outages scattered across our service territory," adding that restoration would start once the extreme weather passed. Delmarva Power reported over 7,500 customers dark in the Salisbury area, while the National Weather Service logged 80-mph gusts and hail. APG Chesapeake Regional President Orestes Baez noted that traffic on Ocean Gateway was “snarled as weekend drivers were not sure how to navigate the waves of wind and rain,” and Talbot County Emergency Services had no damage details by press time.

title: Ridgely man indicted on rape, sex offense charges
author: Natalie Jones
content: Rhett Ritter, 26, of Ridgely was indicted Jan. 18 in Caroline County for second-degree rape, multiple sex-offense degrees and second-degree assault stemming from a January 2012 incident involving a minor. content: Tena Cheaton, 59, said, “So I wanted to come,” to Bradford House when she was homeless, but soon added, “I didn’t realize it was this bad,” detailing how she was drugged and raped in her apartment, then spent weeks “throwing up constantly” and “crying uncontrollably.” After getting a restraining order she still met her assailant in the halls, and on another night, “I had just shut that door,” she recalled, “And somebody standing way down there at the end of the building was hollering at me,” before threatening to shoot her. Cheaton, who struggles with PTSD and addiction, says, “To stay sober in a building like this is very, very difficult,” and wants management to make the place safe.

title: Police investigating serious rollover crash outside Trappe

content: Police are investigating a serious rollover crash that occurred just outside Trappe around 4:30 a.m. Tuesday. title: Police arrest Dorchester County man on rape, sexual assault charges

content: Jason Groff, 41, of Toddville was arrested Monday morning by Cambridge Police with help from the Dorchester County Sheriff’s Office and is being held without bond. After the female victim pulled into a gas station, she and the man went to a Cambridge residence where, according to the release, "the male subject was reported to making lewd comments and advancements on the female victim. The female repeatedly told the male subject 'No' and to 'Stop,' the release states. 'The male subject ended up reportedly overpowering the female victim and she ended up being raped.'" title: Political vandalism reported in Easton ahead of Election Day

content: Easton residents reported political sign vandalism before the 2004 election; Sandra. Chapperr said two of her Harris and Alsobrooks signs were removed and dumped elsewhere. title: Talbot Police Accountability Board gears up for first annual report
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: The Talbot County Police Accountability Board is preparing its first annual report, due to the County Council by Dec. 31, to identify trends in police discipline and recommend policy improvements. The Administrative Charging Committee received 14 complaints from January to August, according to the Talbot County Office of Law. Sheriff Joe Gamble asked the Board to include details on the "amount of time local law enforcement agencies are spending on handling complaints," calling it "an added workload for his office." Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey said he "appreciated how the Administrative Charging Committee's opinions were reasoned out," though he "believed some things were mischaracterized," and added that the 'year and a day' issue needed to be addressed. Board Chair Mitch Ettinger agreed to include that state-mandated timeline concern in the report, with further discussion scheduled for the Dec. 19 meeting.

title: Common sense degrees needed
author: Staff Writer
content: While enjoying the company of “The Thursday Brotherhood,” the narrator recalled his great-grandfather Walter Wood, Easton’s police chief, who earned what the family called a C.S. (common sense) degree by simply opening the firehouse doors each night to give the homeless shelter. Mike’s nostalgic call reminded the writer that, just as Walter used plain compassion to solve problems, today’s updated challenges still yield to perspective and neighborly understanding.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the role of a former police chief, homelessness, and community safety, aligning most closely with the Public Safety topic, while also touching on local governance and social climate.

title: Ophelia a bust but still causes flooding
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: “Luckily we didn’t make out too badly with the storm,” Dorchester Emergency Management Planner Jimmy Windsor said, though the weekend still brought “moderate to borderline-major tidal flooding” along portions of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal rivers, with the road past the Hoopers Island Causeway “took a little bit of a beating.” The Hoopers Island Volunteer Fire Company “assisted some people with getting back to their residences from places they were at on the island after it had started to flood,” Windsor noted, while the National Guard—summoned after Gov. Wes Moore declared a state of emergency—“had brought a couple Humvees with them” and “were just a contingent plan in case we needed them,” doing some advance scouting “just to make sure they knew where they were going if they had to go anywhere.” As of Wednesday, “There is still some high water areas in the lower part of the county, which is not being helped by the fact that we currently have a higher than usual tide cycle,” Windsor said, “But everything is back open.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on flooding from Tropical Storm Ophelia, emergency management actions, road closures, and National Guard deployment, all of which pertain primarily to public safety and emergency response.

title: MD 405 crossover closure to remain until safety improvement implemented
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: After two fatal crashes in three days, the MD 405 median crossover at U.S. Route 301 in Church Hill has been closed indefinitely while SHA designs a permanent safety fix. “Crossings such as MD 19 and Hayden Clark Road are well-marked with flashers to alert drivers to potential cross traffic,” spokesperson Charlie Gischlar noted, adding that the current closure—recommended by the Church Hill Volunteer Fire Department—maintains emergency access. “SHA is committed to improving safety for motorists along this corridor,” Gischlar said. “We are evaluating larger safety improvements; however, our immediate focus is addressing the safety concerns with near-term projects that improve safety conditions and assist motorists in making good driving decisions.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on road closures and safety measures after fatal crashes, focusing on protecting motorists and coordinating with emergency responders, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

title: CHIEF OF POLICE POSITION TOWN OF GREENSBORO
content: The Mayor and Council of Greensboro are accepting applications for a Chief of Police, seeking “someone who is results oriented, has a great attitude, works efficiently, shows a record of success, has a passion for public service and wants to work in a team environment.” The successful candidate must demonstrate “excellent leadership and decision-making skills,” show “fairness to all people,” and be “proficient in writing reports and handling paperwork,” while being willing “to work shift work, nights, weekends and holidays as needed.” Minimum qualifications include Maryland Police Training Commission certification, U.S. citizenship, a high-school diploma (preferably a two-year criminal-justice degree), at least 10 years of administrative and senior-command experience, and a valid Maryland driver’s license. The Town offers “a competitive salary and a generous benefit package including Maryland State Retirement.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article advertises a Chief of Police position, directly relating to law enforcement and public safety functions, making Public Safety the most appropriate category.

title: Police: Suspects caught with Molotov cocktail in truck linked to recent homicide
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Officer McGonigle—who wrote, “I have personally made dozens of arrests in reference to violent crimes and narcotics in this area. Additionally, this area has recently been inundated with violent crime, including a homicide and shooting”—stopped the truck at 12:20 a.m. because it had been “involved in a recent homicide” and because “As I spoke to both Dickerson and Santana, whom I have a rapport with; I noticed they were acting in an unusual manner. Typically, both Dickerson and Santana are very talkative and often joke with me. However, they were unusually quiet and could not maintain eye contact.” A K-9’s “positive alert,” prompted “due to the high crime area, the time of night and the observed behavior,” led to the discovery of a Molotov cocktail “shoved inside the seat cushion, in close proximity to the glass bottle full of gasoline,” and although Santana claimed the rag was only “to stop the gasoline from spilling,” McGonigle noted “the cap from the glass E&J bottle was located in the bed of the truck, conveniently located on the rear wheel well. Dickerson advised he filled the bottle with gasoline.” The incident occurred eight days after a homicide in which a one-armed man stabbed a 14-year-old attacker among a group of “five or six” youths armed with “knives, sticks or clubs,” a case police call “a pretty strong case of self-defense, which would make this a justifiable homicide,” while the trio now face 25-year felony charges for the destructive device and no “smoke-able objects” were found.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police traffic stop, arrests, and a suspected link to a homicide, which are matters of crime and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

people: Timothy Michael Dickerson, 18, of Newark, Del.

title: Local program celebrates 10th summer of free swim lessons for kids
author: Staff Writer
content: SOS Sink or Swim is marking its 10th summer offering free, two-week swim sessions for kids aged 18 months to 18 years at Easton’s George Murphy Pool and St. Michaels’ Bay Hundred Pool, with 2024 sessions starting June 17, July 8, and July 22, "according a release from the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, which helps support the program. The SOS program has provided swimming lessons to 8,000 local kids since its founding 2014." Run by Talbot County Parks & Recreation and partnering with CBMM, BAAM, and Critchlow Adkins Children Centers, the initiative is championed by SOS Sink or Swim President Libby Moose, who said, "Swimming is an essential life skill for all ages, and it is critical for all children on the Eastern Shore to know how to swim and be safe in the water." "We are so proud to have been providing this service for ten years now," Moose said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a community program offering free swimming lessons, emphasizing life‑saving skills and water safety for children, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Mother gets six years for Christmas Day fire that killed daughter, 10
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Judge Davis called the case “the exact definition of a difficult case… the tragic loss of a young person” and told Theresa Moats, “It was totally preventable. I’m not doubting that you love your daughter, but the care wasn’t there,” while prosecutors condemned Moats for refusing responsibility, noting, “The house was in shambles… Kyleigh didn’t have any friends… This child was essentially forgotten,” and describing how “She did not die peacefully. She had soot in her mouth, smoke in her lungs. She burned.” Moats, sentenced to six years for the Christmas Day fire that killed 10-year-old Kyleigh, wept that “Living without my daughter has been like a mental prison… She was the shining star of the family,” as her lawyer termed the blaze a “tragic accident” and blamed social services: “There was no shelter plan, no safety plan… They would have had Kyleigh with them if they had done their job properly.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fatal house fire, neglect, and the resulting criminal sentencing, which are matters of public safety and community protection rather than sports, education, or other categories.

organizations: Cecil County Department of Social Services
Cecil County Department of Animal Services

title: People can get vicious
author: Staff Writer
content: While volunteering at the Firehouse, Catherine Nobles reports being verbally attacked and says, “You are all sick.” She and fellow supporters have been spat on, cursed, flipped off, and even had coffee thrown at them; one 70-year-old woman gave a Trump sign the middle finger. Two women felt so threatened they considered calling the police, leaving Nobles to conclude, “I thought it was bad when the signs were being destroyed, little did I know how viscous people can get.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes verbal and physical threats and harassment at a public event, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Following lockdown, lawmakers express worry over Capitol’s emergency alert system
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content: After Thursday’s two-hour lockdown, lawmakers praised first responders—Senate President Bill Ferguson noting, “Yesterday was certainly a very scary moment for many... but a moment when our first responders did everything that they were supposed to do”—yet lamented the lack of an internal alert, with Sen. Antonio Hayes saying, “I wish I would have gotten a text message internally before I got one externally... it is what it is.” While Sen. Will Folden warned, “The one thing you can’t have happen is, you don’t want to over alert or over alarm... It’s a necessary element to only provide absolutely necessary information to not create panic,” colleagues agreed the planned Motorola text system—still under construction—was urgently needed, as Sen. Sarah Elfreth concluded, “Within the structure we have right now... we all would like a world in which we had a text service to keep us informed.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a security threat, lockdown, and emergency alert communications at the state capitol, which are core issues of public safety.

people: Bill Ferguson, Senate President, D-Baltimore County

title: Denton chief disciplines officers after Administrative Charging Committee gives recommendations
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Denton Police Chief George Bacorn, Jr. said he has "thoroughly reviewed and followed through on" the Caroline County Administrative Charging Committee’s ruling that two officers violated Town of Denton policies during an April 7, 2023 incident. The incident, captured in a YouTube video viewed millions of times, shows Christopher Morgan threatening residents and breaking a storm-door window while the officers watched from the sidewalk. After Bacorn requested an outside investigation by the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office, the committee recommended discipline under the Maryland Uniform Disciplinary Matrix. For Corporal Mark Snyder it recommended “a 10 days loss of leave and/or pay”; Bacorn imposed “five days loss of leave and a five day suspension without pay.” For Corporal Ciaran Mayo it recommended “a 10 day loss of leave and/or pay, as well as a demotion of one rank”; Bacorn imposed “a five days loss of leave, five days suspension without pay and a demotion to patrolman first class.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police disciplinary actions and oversight by a municipal committee, which directly relates to public safety issues.

title: Transcript reveals final words from Dali crew before Key Bridge collapse
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content: Minutes before the Key Bridge collapsed, the Dali pilot casually told a tug, “I like my chances if you want to take off,” and the Bridget McAllister answered, “Alright — all done here. (Have) safe trip.” After a blackout “similar to Automatic Power Change Over Circuit,” the pilot warned, “(Just) let me know if you can’t steer,” then reported “swinging to starboard” and urgently requested a “mac boat,” radioing, “Hey Eric [IMO 9707413] it’s the Dali — I need ya over here quick. I’ve uh just lost power (heading to the Key Bridge).” The command center simultaneously told MDTA, “No there’s a vessel — I’m calling for the pilot. There’s a ship heading toward the Key Bridge. He lost steering. We need to stop all traffic on the Key Bridge,” and the training pilot broadcast, “Security call. Security call. Container ship Dali has lost power. Approaching the Key Bridge — I repeat — the container ship Dali has lost all power approaching the Key Bridge — Dali.” On the bridge, the captain shouted, “Fast, fast let go port anchor,” but the forward replied, “Sir I cannot * * *,” then, after frantic orders of “Let go. Let go” and “Let go, yes,” confessed the anchor was “Not working #,” and when bow thrusters also failed the second officer said, “No. It’s not working,” prompting the pilot’s last words, “Not working #,” seconds before impact at 1:29:06 a.m.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the communications and investigation surrounding the Key Bridge collapse, focusing on safety failures, emergency response, and the NTSB investigation, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Chamber of Commerce partners with Sheriff in fight against opioid overdoses
author: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat
content: Sheriff Gary Hofmann and Chamber president Linda Friday on Monday handed out free ONEbox opioid-overdose kits to 11 local businesses; each kit contains Narcan, protective gear and bilingual training video. Program coordinator Rebecca Groff said, “The goal is to distribute these kits to businesses throughout the county, regardless of their size,” while Friday noted, “QAC businesses give all the time to worthwhile community causes.” The joint effort of the Chamber, County Commissioners, Drug Free Coalition, Health Department and Sheriff’s Department is providing the kits at no cost, and as Prevention Specialist Anna Ashley coordinates distribution, Sheriff Hofmann urges businesses to claim boxes while supplies last. Wright summed up the collaboration: “This is a great example of the community coming together — everyone working together makes tasks easier.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a safety initiative—distribution of opioid overdose reversal kits by the sheriff’s office and Chamber of Commerce—to protect the public from overdose deaths, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: Solar panel fire damages Chestertown home
author: STAFF REPORTS
content: A May 2 roof fire that began in solar panels damaged a two-story home on Great Oak Landing Road in Chestertown, with flames first spotted around 5:30 p.m. "Due to the location and timing of the incident, there was a delayed response," said Chestertown Volunteer Fire Company Chief J. Darling. Crews used garden hoses until additional units arrived, then deployed two hand lines—one to the roof fire and one to the attic—keeping flames confined to the second-floor attic and the panel-bearing roof section, according to fire officials. The Maryland State Fire Marshal's Office blamed the solar panels, notified Tesla, and reported no injuries. Eight volunteer companies from Kent and Queen Anne's counties responded. Officials warned, "As more homes install solar panels, it's important for homeowners to understand the potential fire risks and how to reduce them. While solar panels are generally safe and highly regulated, like any electrical system, they can pose hazards if improperly installed, damaged or affected by environmental factors."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire caused by solar panels and the response of fire and emergency services, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.
