title: Man Arrested In Connection With Shooting, Escape At Hospital
author: Natalie Jones; Njones@Chespub. Com
content: Israel Labastida, Jr., 19, of Glen Burnie was arrested Tuesday for allegedly shooting into a window at Eastern Shore Hospital Center on Aug. 1, allowing patient Darrin Lee Jeter, 19, to escape. “Security officers on scene at the hospital told police that an unknown person in a black vehicle approached the building and shot several times into a glass window. The unknown person then kicked the broken window out, which allowed a hospital patient to escape with the unknown person in the black vehicle,” police said. Labastida is charged with conspiracy to escape, multiple assault counts, reckless endangerment, firearm offenses, and malicious destruction over $1,000; police also seized “a loaded 9mm handgun” from his home. Jeter, originally committed for assaulting Montgomery County officers, was later found and charged with first-degree escape; he is being held without bond while his case is pending in Dorchester County Circuit Court. Labastida is held without bond ahead of a Wednesday bail review in Glen Burnie District Court.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police investigation, arrest, and criminal charges related to a shooting and escape at a hospital, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

people: Israel Labastida, Jr., 19, of Glen Burnie

title: YMCA fire on Saturday intentionally set, fire marshal says
author: Konner Metz
content: The Office of the State Fire Marshal ruled Saturday’s first YMCA blaze “incendiary,” calling it “disheartening to know that that can happen,” said YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill, who noted “The Y's been in this community 168 years. It serves one in three people. It's kind of a third place where people go. It's a place where everyone is welcome.” Board president Peter Hyman, arriving as staff gathered afterward, said, “The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation,” while Gill added the attack is “always scary at the time and also sad.” Yet, he insisted, “But if there's one thing about Talbot County and our community, it is a tight group of people... Something like this isn't going to deter us from continuing to make a positive impact.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an intentionally set fire, the fire marshal's investigation, and the response by firefighters, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Prosecutors: 80-year-old man who fatally shot son won't be charged
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: An 80-year-old man who fatally shot his son on Sept. 24 in Conowango will not be charged, as prosecutors determined he acted in self-defense. "Following a thorough review of the evidence, Maryland State Police investigators determined that the deceased was shot while attempting to break into the home after an earlier physical and verbal altercation with the resident elderly couple. After a review of the current statute, case law, and all information gathered by the Maryland State Police, the Office of the State's Attorney has elected to not proceed with criminal charges. In these circumstances, the suspect was protecting himself and his wife and was acting in self-defense," an SAO spokeswoman said. The man's 78-year-old wife was injured during the incident and was treated at Upper Chesapeake Medical Center. A separate fire at an adjacent home was ruled "undetermined" by the State Fire Marshal.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation and prosecutorial decision regarding a fatal shooting, which falls under public safety and law enforcement matters.

title: Police: Couple robbed homeless man inside his tent
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Police say that “longtime friends” Brandy Gibbs and Justin Hand stormed into a homeless man’s tent near Elkton’s West Pulaski Highway, where Gibbs demanded money and then told Hand to kill him after accusing the man of “being smart with” her. Hand allegedly beat the victim with a “metal metal blunt object,” and only when Gibbs yelled “Stop,” did the pair flee, stealing $150 and a bicycle and destroying the tent. The victim, who called them “longtime friends,” described Gibbs as “an older white female of medium build with no teeth” and Hand as a “skinty build with face tattoos,” noting her last name started with “G.” “Due to the suspect descriptions, officers believed the suspect description provided matched those of Brussell and Hand, who(m) officers are familiar with through prior contact,” records state.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a violent robbery and assault investigated by police, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

title: Lawmakers work toward juvenile justice solution
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content: Sen. Will Smith pledged lawmakers will “do whatever makes sense to ensure that, obviously, our youth have the supports to succeed and public safety is upheld,” while the House prefers a police-chosen “diversion program” and the Senate would send first-time auto-theft cases to court via a “CINS petition” so kids still “have the ability to get services and support, but there will be a level of accountability there.” Del. Luke Clippinger, though “happy to hear more from the Senate,” warns the “special kind of CINS, at least how it is described to me, sounds an awful lot like just putting kids at the Department of Juvenile Services” and notes CINS “has been administered disparately,” whereas public defenders say that when children are ruled incompetent “then we’re high and dry, and we can’t get them whatever it is they need.” Sen. William Folden adds the bill isn’t “as far-reaching as we would like to have had,” but stresses “That’s an important component, being able to have that recall authority of the judge to say that their sentencing and their guidelines have some teeth,” even as he laments that under current law “That type of candid dialogue is now gone because the officer can’t talk (with the young person) even with parental consent.” Del. Cheryl Pasteur, who voted yes after penalties were “ameliorated,” urged colleagues to heed the commission because “We have commissions, and sometimes the seats don’t get filled. We don’t take them seriously. This time, we need to take it seriously.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislative changes to Maryland's juvenile justice system, focusing on crime prevention, rehabilitation, and court processes, which are core aspects of public safety.

title: Kent County weighs ICE cooperation amid liability concerns
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: Kent County Sheriff Dennis Hickman says the county will share fingerprints with ICE under the Secure Communities Program to “identify criminal aliens in state prisons and local jails by running their fingerprints against federal immigration databases when they are locked in the system,” but will not sign a 287(g) agreement, explaining, “As the elected sheriff, I don't want to potentially cause additional liability to me or our county government, but we don't want the same problems that we have seen in other counties.” While Democratic lawmakers push back—“We should not be doing the federal government's job for them,” argued Delegate Nicole Williams, and Sen. Will Smith’s “protected spaces” bill would restrict ICE actions in churches and schools—Hickman maintains that “Some counties refuse to cooperate with the federal government, resulting in releasing potentially dangerous people back into the community,” concluding, “Failing to have some measure of cooperation is not in the best interest of our community.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on law‑enforcement cooperation with ICE, liability, and community safety concerns, which are central to public safety, while also involving local government policy decisions.

title: 'It was all smiles': Cambridge National Night Out brings more than 800 to county pool
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd called the Aug. 6 National Night Out “another successful year,” noting, “We had tons of kids and a lot of people and businesses and community leaders that came out and all took part. It was all smiles.” More than 800 neighbors packed the county pool where kids swam free—“I think there’s just something about being at the county pool and the kids being able to have the opportunity to swim for a couple hours, not worry about any prices or charges and just enjoy time with their friends and family,” Todd said—while 30-plus vendors handed out vital resources: “And it’s good because you get those necessary resources and information that people may not otherwise see or get. It actually gets handed to them. And they can talk to one another and start forming those bonds.” Prize giveaways thrilled the crowd—“The lady who won a TV actually cried,” Captain Antoine Patton recalled—and, beyond fun, the night advanced community policing: “It’s building relationships between the police and the community,” Todd explained. “But also (building) other relationships such as (with) Juvenile Services, the health department, the Dorchester County school system. ... Us all working together to build a stronger community for tomorrow.” Patton added, “And what it does is it brings community together and it gives them a live interaction with law enforcement officers to let the community know that we’re working together and we support them just like they support us.” His closing verdict: “It was a great event and we look forward to doing it again.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community policing event (National Night Out) organized by the Cambridge Police Department, highlighting safety, police-community relations, and public safety resources.

title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content: Democratic leaders say their new youth-crime package will fix a "system" where "Egos, political operations and arguments over process have filled the" ("Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps") and call for "accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system." Critics, however, warn that "legislation introduced today will see thousands more kids incarcerated every than year, particularly Black and brown children, and (exacerbate) the already serious racial disparities in Maryland's juvenile justice system." Despite Republican criticism, House Minority Leader Jason Buckel praised the plan as "first steps" to reform and applauded Governor Wes. "For him to be able to step in and say, 'Hey, I'm a Democrat. I'm from Baltimore City, but I'm going to step up and say too much is too much and this is a reasonable way to deal with this' — it's incredibly helpful," Buckel said.

title: St. Michaels peeping Tom sentenced to 3 years
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Diego Albarado Lopez, 31, of St. Michaels was sentenced Oct. 18 to “three years and 90 days of active incarceration” by Talbot District Court Judge Karen Ketterman after being found guilty of stalking, harassment and trespassing as a peeping Tom. The charges arose from April 12 surveillance footage showing “the man walking toward the residents' bedroom window and holding his hands near his groin area,” and the residents recognized Lopez from his “March 2022 attempt to burglarize their home.” Lopez had already “been previously convicted of being a peeping Tom and trespassing in May 2022 for following women home and peering in windows,” for which he received “4.5 months in jail and three years of supervised probation.” He will receive roughly six months’ credit for time served, faces three years of supervised probation on release, and must undergo a mental health evaluation and complete mental health and alcohol treatment.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and police involvement, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Maryland State Police investigating two late-night fatal crashes in Queen Anne’s, Kent counties
author: Staff Writer
content: Maryland State Police are investigating two late-night fatal crashes, one in Queen Anne’s County and one in Kent County, both occurring late Saturday. In Centreville, a two-vehicle crash involving a motorcycle on northbound U.S. Route 301 at Hayden Clark Road left motorcycle operator Marcus Dangerfield, 20, of Dover, Delaware, pronounced dead at the scene, while the GMC Acadia driver, 45, and a passenger, 38, were hospitalized. “The preliminary investigation indicates the GMC was traveling east on Hayden Clark Road, attempting to cross northbound U.S. Route 301, when it was struck by the motorcycle for unknown reasons,” police said. In Chestertown, a single-vehicle crash on Maryland Route 213 at Riley's Mill Road killed a 17-year-old boy and injured the 19-year-old driver and three other passengers; “Investigators believe impairment may have been a factor,” police noted.

title: Chester woman charged in January Bay Bridge crash
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Gwendolyn Persina, 48, of Chester, was charged this week for the Jan. 27 Bay Bridge crash involving 20-plus vehicles while she was allegedly DUI and on a suspended license. title: Bay Bridge to hold traffic temporarily today
author: Staff Writer
content: The Maryland Transportation Authority will hold Bay Bridge traffic for 15-30 minutes between 11 a.m. and noon “out of an abundance of caution as the M/V Dali passes beneath the bridge on its way to Norfolk,” escorted by four tugs. Authorities said the temporary closure will “avoid the risk of motorists driving over the Bay trying to look at the ship involved in the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore,” and “undue traffic congestion is not anticipated on the east side of the bridge.” Travelers can call 1-877-BAYSPAN or follow @TheMDTA on X for updates.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a temporary traffic hold on the Bay Bridge for safety reasons, involving the Maryland Transportation Authority, Coast Guard, and sheriff's office, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: 400 flags placed to honor heroes this Memorial Day weekend
author: Konner Metz
content:
Civil Air Patrol cadets and Easton Rotary Club members placed over 400 flags in front of the Talbot County Community Center, despite "Rainy and windy conditions" on Wednesday. "Mellinger said recognizing fallen heroes with the patriotic display is extremely meaningful."  
The display is part of the Rotary Club's Flags for Heroes initiative, which has honored veterans, law enforcement, first responders, teachers, and health care workers every May since 2012.  
This year, flags were also placed at Idlewild Park, Aqua Pools & Spas, and Londonderry on the Tred Avon.  
Rotary Club Secretary George Hatcher said the tradition "has never failed to be something that brings people together."  
The Easton Rotary Club has raised nearly $600,000 since 2012 through donations from flag sponsors, with proceeds benefiting local organizations including the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Easton Police Department, Civil Air Patrol, and local fire departments.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community flag display honoring veterans, law enforcement, fire, and other first responders, making public safety the most relevant category, with secondary relevance to local government and fundraising aspects.

title: Case for woman charged with assault of toddler at child care center made inactive
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Linda Perry, 77, had her assault and neglect charges placed on the stet docket after video showed her spanking a "crying and screaming" toddler, then dropping him to the floor at Best Buddies Learning Center. One witness called Perry "overly aggressive," and court records say she warned the boy, “You better not kick me,” before smacking him and leaving him on his back. Judge Karen Ketterman made the case inactive on conditions that Perry avoid the child and his family, cease providing child care to non-relatives, and complete a mental-health evaluation scheduled for September.

title: Scammers look to lure voters to get information
author: MORGAN LEASON Capital News Service
content: Jared DeMarinis of Maryland’s State Board of Elections warns that scammers are texting voters with “URGENT,” fake “not-registered” alerts: “They’re capitalizing on the hypertension involving this election. The text message is urgent, and they’re playing on a fear that an individual is not registered to vote when they really are.” DeMarinis insists officials must act fast—“You don’t wait until things hit critical mass”—because “These scams are a direct threat to the legitimacy of the electoral process, because, at best, they’re just trying to steal identities. But at worst, they’re there to kind of sow distrust in an election administration and undermine confidence in the system.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on fraudulent scams targeting voters and the threat they pose to election integrity, which aligns with public safety concerns about fraud and misinformation.

title: Suspect charged in Sunday Federalsburg shooting
content: A Federalsburg man has been charged with attempted murder after a trespassing dispute early Sunday morning, Sept. 24. "According to Caroline Sheriff Donald Baker, the suspect, Thomas Barr, fired two rifle rounds at the victim striking him in the chest," police said. The victim, Gregory Hobbs, was transported to TidalHealth Nanticoke in Seaford before being transferred to Christiana Hospital. The 51-year-old Barr was charged with attempted second degree murder, reckless endangerment, assault first degree, assault second degree, using a firearm during the commission of a felony and possession of a rifle and possession of ammunition by a prohibited person. He is being held without bond pending trial.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident (a shooting) and the subsequent police response and charges, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: VETERANS, FIRST RESPONDERS HONORED AT BLUE MASS
content: First responders and veterans were honored Nov. 4 at a Blue Mass celebrated by the Rev. Christopher Coffiey at St. Benedict Catholic Church in Ridgely. Participants included Marshal Eastern Shore Michael Ragolio, retired Caroline County Chief Deputy Sid Pinder, retired Anne Arundel County Fire Captain Dan Tuel, Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker, retired Navy Reserve chaplain Father Coffiey, Caroline County EMS Division Chief K.J. Marvel, Vietnam War veteran Deacon Bill Nickum, retired Annapolis City Police PFC Ronald Little, Queen Anne's County firefighter and EMT Alex Marvel, Caroline County EMS Lt. Todd Lauren, and Knights of Columbus Color Corps Commander Jim Jennings.

title: Two arrested in shooting death at Easton bar
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Police arrested Kevron Chase, 34, of Cambridge and Chadnee Harris, 32, of Hurlock in the Sept. 30 shooting death of 23-year-old Antonio L. Smith outside Easton’s Sidetracked Saloon. Chase is charged with first- and second-degree murder and related gun counts; Harris is charged as an accessory after the fact. Security footage reportedly shows Chase pointing a handgun at Smith during a parking-lot fight, then “a muzzle flash from the gun and Smith collapse in between two cars.” Chase, who told police he fired one shot but “denied shooting Smith,” and Harris were ordered held without bond Monday by Judge Karen Ketterman “citing concerns about public safety.” Both are set for preliminary hearings Oct. 30.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a shooting death, arrests, and police actions, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Police investigating weekend shooting in Ridgely
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Caroline County Sheriff’s Office is investigating a non-fatal Saturday-night shooting at the Daysprings Townhomes in Ridgely, where an adult male was found with a hand wound and hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries. Maryland State Police crime scene unit responded "to collect and preserve physical evidence in support of the investigation," according to a release. No suspect has been identified; the county’s Criminal Investigations Division asks anyone with information to call (410) 479-2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police investigation of a local shooting incident, which directly pertains to public safety concerns.

title: Laurel man arrested for vehicle theft in Easton
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Easton police stopped 20-year-old Donya Jenkins-Patterson in a white Chevy Silverado on May 30 after responding to "suspicious activity" at Hertrich Chevrolet GMC, police said. Officers "noticed the passenger side window was broken and noticed ammunition and equipment that 'appeared to be law enforcement-related' in the vehicle," the release states. A second person was seen "fleeing" into nearby woods, and a parked Dorchester County Sheriff's Office vehicle was found with its passenger window broken, making it "unclear whether the suspect had obtained a firearm," police said. Police later linked Jenkins-Patterson to the May 29 theft of the Silverado from Baltimore and to vehicle break-ins in Queen Anne's County; meanwhile, a second stolen vehicle, a 2024 Chevy Traverse, was recovered in the Hebron area and is believed to have been taken by the still-at-large second suspect.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police response, arrest, and investigation of vehicle theft, which falls under public safety and law‑enforcement matters.

title: Caroline CASA honors armed forces veterans
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content: CASA of Caroline’s Veterans Day Heroes Breakfast honored veterans while underscoring the shared mission of “protecting tomorrow’s future - our children,” as Executive Director Amy Horne said the nonprofit that “advocates for the best interest of all abused and neglected children who are in the Caroline County court system through no fault of their own” wants to recognize veterans who “protect our freedoms, just like our advocates are the people who protect the rights of the children we serve.” Former Marine and CASA board president Keith Johnson, whose wife is an advocate, explained “Why is CASA, a child advocacy group, hosting a Veterans Day (event)?” by noting that veterans’ “Discipline, fighting spirit, leadership, resiliency” make them “mission-ready” volunteers, adding, “As a (Maryland State) trooper, I served about three years as the primary investigator for Caroline County for the Maryland State Police, dealing with child abuse, child neglect” and stressing, “There’s a need in our county for advocates because our children are underserved and our children live as victims of abuse and victims of neglect every day.” Horne echoed Sen. Ben Cardin’s “profound admiration for the unwavering service and sacrifices of our veterans,” and Johnson closed with, “If you’re not an advocate, think about what you can do different this year,” because “Our advocates make a difference every day, our staff makes a difference every day” and “Anybody who has had the courage to put on the uniform is a hero in my mind.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event honoring armed forces veterans and mentions a former state trooper and child protection work, linking it to public safety themes rather than the other listed categories.

title: Jury acquits woman who stabbed two women in neighborhood fight
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Lacey Siple, acquitted of all charges after stabbing two women during a neighborhood clash, told jurors, “I was just trying to get home, calling the incident a “more significant fight,” but insisted, “There was no mob,” and that she never meant to hurt anybody. Prosecutor Ellis Rollins argued Siple was the “initial aggressor,” saying, “She (Sipline) was the. She started it and she was going to end it,” and “She raised it to a deadly force level. She upped the. She brought a knife to a fistfight,” adding, “She didn't just slash the victims; she stabbed them,.” Defense attorney Denise Winston countered, “My client acted in self-defense,” noting, “Every time there was an interaction, it happened outside of her house. They went to her; she didn't come to them,” and that bruising could occur “If you're twisting and turning, you can get stabbed all over the place.” Winston emphasized body-cam audio captured Siple’s terror, then calm once police arrived: “She screamed, ‘Who is that?’… Then that recording reflects a calmness in Siple's voice when she learns that it is police officers knocking on her door, according to Winston. ‘She says, ‘OK, OK, let me unlock the door’,” Winston told the jurors. Summarizing toward the end of closing argument, Winston commented, “They brought the fight to her. She just wanted to go home.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal trial and jury verdict, which falls under public safety and law‑enforcement news rather than the other listed categories.

title: Queen Anne's County man added to Animal Abuse Registry
author: Staff Writer
content: Troy Michael Sellman, 37, of Queenstown, has been added to the Queen Anne's County Animal Abuse Registry after pleading guilty to animal abuse charges, according to Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson. Sellman entered a guilty plea in Queen Anne's County District Court on Nov. 24, 2024, for failing to provide proper shelter for a Cane Corso dog, violating Maryland Criminal Law Article 10-604, Richardson said. In August 2024, county animal control officers responded to an anonymous tip about a dog in distress at Sellman's Thompson Avenue residence, Richardson reported, and found the Cane Corso tethered with a choker collar in direct sunlight without shelter or water; the dog was heavily panting in critical condition, with an external temperature of 121 degrees when the air temperature was 96 degrees. Officers transported the animal to a nearby clinic where it was pronounced dead upon arrival, according to Richardson. Sellman received a suspended jail sentence and supervised probation, as he was already incarcerated on unrelated charges, Richardson said, and his probation conditions prohibit him from owning or possessing animals and require a mental health evaluation.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case involving animal abuse and the county's Animal Abuse Registry, which is a public safety matter. While it involves a county ordinance (local government), the primary focus is on the crime and its enforcement.

title: Greensboro contractor sentenced for felony home improvement fraud
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Jeremy Bowen, 44, was sentenced June 20 to six months in prison after pleading guilty to three counts of felony home improvement fraud for taking payments on 13 contracts—many involving pool projects for seniors—without completing the work. Delaware Attorney General Kathy Jennings said, “Jeremy Bowen’s deceitful actions didn’t just hurt his victims financially — they caused a great deal of emotional and psychological distress to several families across our state,” adding, “Delawareans throughout the state pour their life savings into buying and then improving their homes; they need to be able to trust their contractors and that their funds will be used as promised. My white collar crime unit will continue to hold contractors who breach that trust accountable.” Bowen must also pay about $270,000 in restitution, serve a year of home confinement, and is barred from home-improvement work for 4½ years.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal conviction and sentencing for home improvement fraud, which is primarily a public safety issue concerning crime and consumer protection, though it also touches on business practices and court actions.

author: Staff Writer
content: Mid-Shore towns, long familiar with flooding that has “affected every community I have worked in — a major road washed out by stormwater or a business protecting its merchandise from knee-high surge,” are now pursuing concrete solutions to better withstand future storms, the Star Democrat’s Ahmad Garnett reports.

title: Helmer Sworn In As Chief Deputy
author: Connie Connolly; Cconnolly@Chespub.Com
content: Sheriff Donnie Baker, calling Helmer “true blue,” said, “R.J. has been with me through thick and thin at the sheriff’s office… He is an absolutely hardworking individual and a very capable individual to be my chief deputy and to lead this agency to the next level,” adding, “It wasn’t really a hard choice for me.” Former Sheriff Randy Bounds praised, “R.J. is an outstanding police officer, a wonderful human being and one of the hardest working people that I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with… It was an honor to hire him… He’s knowledgeable, energetic, and most supremely of all, he cares about those with whom he interacts. You will never, ever have to worry about his dedication and loyalty. He will serve the citizens of Caroline County well.” After being sworn in, Helmer told attendees, “I thank Sheriff Baker for the opportunity, and I wouldn’t have this opportunity if it weren’t for Sheriff Bounds… It’s a pleasure to work with each and every one of you, and I look forward to doing everything to the best of my ability.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the swearing-in of a chief deputy for a county sheriff's office, which is a law‑enforcement activity and thus falls under public safety.

title: Attorney takes on ICE on Eastern Shore
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: Criminal defense attorney Ivette Furneisen says, “Under Trump however, people are being picked up for minor offenses and then targeted by ICE,” adding, “In general, I see that people are being picked up and detained for minor traffic offenses.” She reports, “I am seeing a lot of failure to appear in court, especially for minor traffic violations, and that makes things worse for those facing charges,” and “I tell them they need to show up for court with a lawyer.” Furneisen explains, “That’s why I fight so hard for them. If I can get them out of jail at the bail review, they will have a better chance to stay with their families. If they go to jail, their life in the U.S. is over,” though “I am swamped with work of this nature.” Warning that “The problem is that this will lead to indefinite detention because there is a backlog in immigration court. These people could be detained for years before they have their immigration hearing,” she concedes, “That’s why I fight so hard to keep them here, but sometimes everything goes against you and you lose those battles.” Noting, “They work in the county, they pay taxes and they are contributing, but they are still getting deported,” and that “In the past ICE has placed a detainer on illegal immigrants who were being held on local charges, but when the sentence was over they were required to come get them. That practice has not changed,” Furneisen affirms, “Just because you’re being charged with a crime doesn’t mean you did it. I love my job in helping those who don’t have a voice and being an advocate for them.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on immigration enforcement, ICE actions, and the attorney's role in protecting clients from detention, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety.

title: Police seeking information in Bay Bridge crash
author: Staff Writer
content: Maryland Transportation Authority Police are investigating a 23-vehicle crash on the westbound Bay Bridge on Jan. 27. Investigators believe a blue 2018 Honda Civic sedan "was being driven at high speeds and erratically prior to the crash and may have contributed to the crash." Witnesses who saw the blue Honda Civic on westbound US-50 near the Bay Bridge between approximately 7:30 and 7:45 a.m. are asked to call 443-454-8703. "Police said the reconstruction is a detailed process that typically takes months to complete as investigators analyze evidence such as interviews, physical evidence, medical records and more," and any potential charges are pending the investigation's conclusion.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a major traffic crash, focusing on safety, witness assistance, and law enforcement actions, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Rape charges against Cambridge man dropped; now facing 8 counts of sextortion
author: Konner Metz
content: Devonte Rodriguez, 37, no longer faces rape charges after prosecutors dropped them, but now faces eight sextortion counts tied to the same 2024 incidents, Dorchester County State’s Attorney Amanda Leonard confirmed. Court records allege Rodriguez demanded explicit photos and videos from an 18-year-old woman, threatening to have her “physically assaulted by other parties for her failure to comply,” and in two instances the woman did “acquiesce to the demands.” Investigators said the threats “inflicted emotional distress,” and social-media messages revealed “her declining mental state and depression.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on criminal charges and court proceedings, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.
